docs.title: 🚀 VibeLearning
docs.text:
Your comprehensive guide to fundamental programming concepts

Welcome to VibeLearning — an exhaustive, beginner-friendly repository designed to take you from programming fundamentals to confident coder. All concepts are explained with Python examples, balancing theory with practical code.

docs.title: 📚 What's Inside
docs.text:
Module Description 00 - Getting Started Setup, installation, how to use this repo 01 - Foundations Variables, operators, control flow, functions 02 - Data Structures Lists, dicts, trees, graphs, and more 03 - Algorithms Searching, sorting, recursion, dynamic programming 04 - OOP Concepts Classes, inheritance, polymorphism, SOLID 05 - Functional Programming Pure functions, higher-order functions, closures 06 - Software Design DRY, KISS, YAGNI, coupling & cohesion 07 - Design Patterns Creational, structural, behavioral patterns 08 - Error Handling Exceptions, defensive programming, logging 09 - Testing Unit tests, TDD, mocking 10 - File & I/O Reading/writing files, JSON, CSV 11 - Memory & Performance Big-O, complexity, optimization 12 - Concurrency Threads, async, synchronization 13 - Modules & Packages Imports, virtual environments 14 - Debugging Debuggers, tracebacks, common bugs 15 - Version Control Git fundamentals 16 - Essential Libraries Collections, datetime, itertools, pathlib, regex, JSON/CSV, hashing

Plus: Exercises, Projects, and Resources!

docs.title: 🎯 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8+ installed on your system
  • A code editor (VS Code, PyCharm, or any text editor)
  • Curiosity and willingness to learn!

docs.title: Recommended Learning Path
docs.text:
1. Start with 00_getting_started/ - Make sure your environment is set up
  2. Follow the numbered modules - They're ordered from basic to advanced
  3. For each concept:
  4. Read the README.md for theory and explanations
  5. Run examples.py to see the concept in action
  6. Try exercises.py to practice
  7. Check quiz.md to test your understanding

docs.title: Structure of Each Module
docs.text:
concept_name/
├── README.md      # Theory, explanation, real-world analogies
├── examples.py    # Runnable code examples
├── exercises.py   # Practice problems
└── quiz.md        # Quick knowledge check

docs.title: Running Examples
docs.text:
# Navigate to any concept folder
cd 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types

# Run the examples
python examples.py

docs.title: 📊 Progress Tracking
docs.text: Check PROGRESS.md to see which modules are complete and what's coming next.

docs.title: 🛤️ Learning Roadmap
docs.text: See ROADMAP.md for a detailed learning path with time estimates.

docs.title: 💡 Tips for Success
docs.text:
1. Don't just read — code along! Type out the examples yourself
  2. Experiment — Modify the examples and see what happens
  3. Practice consistently — 30 minutes daily beats 5 hours once a week
  4. Use the exercises — They're designed to reinforce learning
  5. Ask questions — If something doesn't make sense, dig deeper

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing
docs.text:
Found a bug? Have a suggestion? Contributions are welcome!

  1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a feature branch
  3. Make your changes
  4. Submit a pull request

docs.title: 📝 License
docs.text:
This project is open source and available for educational purposes.

Happy Learning! 🎉

Remember: Every expert was once a beginner.

docs.title: VibeLearning - AI Agent Guide
docs.text:
Last Updated: 2026-01-28

This guide is for AI coding agents working on the VibeLearning repository. This is an educational Python repository—no build system, no dependencies, no deployment.

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
VibeLearning is a comprehensive, self-contained educational repository designed to teach programming fundamentals using Python. It progresses from absolute beginner concepts (variables, types) through advanced topics (concurrency, design patterns, version control).

Key Facts: - Language: Python 3.8+ - Dependencies: None (stdlib only) - Build System: None (direct script execution) - Total Files: ~180 Python files, ~250 Markdown files across 273 directories - Lines of Code: ~36,000

docs.title: Topic Directory Structure
docs.text:
Each topic within a module follows a consistent 4-file pattern:

topic_name/
├── README.md       # Theory, explanations, code snippets
├── examples.py     # Runnable demonstration code
├── exercises.py    # Practice problems with solutions
└── quiz.md         # Knowledge check questions

Exception: Version Control module (15_version_control) uses examples.sh (bash scripts) instead of examples.py.

docs.title: Core Requirements
docs.text:
• Python: 3.8 or higher
  • Standard Library Only: No pip install required
  • Optional: pytest (mentioned in testing module examples only)

docs.title: What This Means for Agents
docs.text:
• No package management: No requirements.txt, pyproject.toml, setup.py, or Pipfile
  • No virtual environment needed: The code is designed to run with system Python
  • No build step: Execute scripts directly with python filename.py

docs.title: Python Style
docs.text:
• Naming: snake_case for variables/functions, PascalCase for classes
  • Docstrings: Module-level docstrings with = underlines; function docstrings for public APIs
  • Comments: Section headers use # ===... style block comments
  • String formatting: F-strings preferred (f"value: {var}")
  • Type hints: Optional but present in newer modules (09+)

docs.title: Example Pattern (from examples.py files):
docs.text:
"""
Module Name - Examples
======================
Brief description of what this demonstrates.
"""

print("=" * 50)
print("MODULE NAME - Examples")
print("=" * 50)

# =============================================================================
# SECTION HEADER
# =============================================================================
print("\n--- Section Description ---\n")

# Code examples with clear variable names
user_name = "Alice"
print(f"Hello, {user_name}!")

# ... more sections ...

print("\n" + "=" * 50)
print("Examples complete! Try exercises.py next.")
print("=" * 50)

docs.title: Exercise Pattern (from exercises.py files):
docs.text:
"""
Module Name - Exercises
=======================
Try to solve each exercise before looking at the solution!
Solutions are provided at the bottom of this file.
"""

# EXERCISE HEADER with description in comments
print("\n--- Exercise N: Title ---\n")
"""
Exercise description here...
"""

# Your code here:
# variable = ...

# SOLUTIONS section at the bottom
print("\n" + "=" * 50)
print("SOLUTIONS")
print("=" * 50)

docs.title: Execute Examples
docs.text:
cd 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types
python examples.py

docs.title: Execute Exercises
docs.text:
cd 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types
python exercises.py

docs.title: Run Tests (Testing Module)
docs.text:
cd 09_testing/02_unit_testing
python examples.py        # Uses unittest
# OR
pytest exercises.py       # If pytest is installed

docs.title: Version Control Examples
docs.text:
cd 15_version_control/01_git_basics
# Read examples.sh - do not execute blindly
cat examples.sh

docs.title: Approach
docs.text:
• Primary: Python's built-in unittest module
  • Secondary: Plain assertions for simple demonstrations
  • Style: Both unittest.TestCase classes and pytest-style functions

docs.title: Test File Locations
docs.text:
• Tests are embedded within examples.py and exercises.py files
  • No separate tests/ directory
  • Module 09 (Testing) demonstrates pytest conventions but uses stdlib

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
# From within a testing module example
if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main(exit=False)

docs.title: When Adding New Content
docs.text:
1. Follow the 4-file structure: README.md, examples.py, exercises.py, quiz.md

  2. README.md sections:

  3. Title with emoji
  4. Concept explanation with real-world analogies
  5. Code examples in fenced blocks
  6. Common mistakes section
  7. Quick reference table

  8. "Next Steps" linking to examples.py

  9. examples.py sections:

  10. Module docstring with title
  11. Visual header/footer with = characters
  12. Logical sections with block comment headers
  13. Progressive complexity

  14. Clear print statements showing results

  15. exercises.py sections:

  16. Exercise descriptions in docstrings
  17. # Your code here: placeholders
  18. Solutions at the bottom (clearly marked)

  19. Encouraging footer

  20. quiz.md format:

  21. 5-10 questions per topic
  22. Multiple choice or short answer
  23. Answers at the bottom

docs.title: Writing Style
docs.text:
• Tone: Encouraging, beginner-friendly
  • Explanations: Use analogies (boxes, jars, light switches)
  • Code: Start simple, gradually add complexity
  • Comments: Explain the "why" not just the "what"

docs.title: Cross-Platform Compatibility
docs.text:
• Use chr(10) instead of \n when Unicode might cause issues (seen in Windows CP1251 contexts)
  • Avoid platform-specific libraries
  • Shell scripts (.sh) in version control module are for demonstration only

docs.title: Unicode Handling
docs.text:
• Be mindful of Unicode characters (emojis, special symbols)
  • Some exercises adjusted to avoid console encoding issues on Windows

docs.title: Git/Version Control Module
docs.text:
• Uses bash scripts instead of Python
  • Commands are demonstrative—users should read, not blindly execute
  • Includes .gitignore examples for Python projects

docs.title: Adding a New Topic
docs.text:
1. Create directory under appropriate module
  2. Add the 4 standard files
  3. Follow naming convention: NN_descriptive_name/
  4. Update module README.md with link
  5. Update PROGRESS.md

docs.title: Fixing Code
docs.text:
• Maintain backward compatibility (Python 3.8+)
  • Keep examples runnable as standalone scripts
  • Ensure exercises have solutions at the bottom

docs.title: Adding Projects
docs.text: Projects go in Projects/ with: - README.md (requirements, steps, testing guide) - Optional: solution.py or main.py template - Optional: challenges.md for extensions

docs.title: Adding Exercises
docs.text: Follow the existing difficulty organization: - Beginner: Variables, loops, functions, basic data structures - Intermediate: OOP, algorithms, error handling, file I/O - Advanced: System design, concurrency, optimization, security

docs.title: Key Files to Reference
docs.text: File Purpose README.md Main project overview, navigation ROADMAP.md Learning timeline (18-20 weeks) PROGRESS.md Implementation status tracker Resources/glossary.md 50+ programming terms defined Resources/cheatsheets/*.md Quick syntax reference

docs.title: Important Reminders
docs.text:
1. No External Dependencies: Do not add requirements.txt or import non-stdlib packages
  2. Educational Focus: Code prioritizes clarity over optimization
  3. Consistent Structure: Always follow the 4-file pattern for topics
  4. Self-Contained: Each examples.py should run independently
  5. Beginner-Friendly: Assume reader is learning programming, not just Python

docs.title: Summary for Quick Reference
docs.text:
# Run any example
python examples.py

# Run any exercise
python exercises.py

# No build, no install, no dependencies
# Just Python 3.8+ and curiosity!

This is a learning resource. Keep code clear, well-commented, and educational.

docs.title: Project 05: Quiz Game
docs.text: Concept: Multiple-choice quiz with categories, scoring, and high scores. Key Features: - Question bank loaded from JSON - Timer per question - Score tracking and leaderboards - Difficulty levels

docs.title: Project 06: Personal Journal
docs.text: Concept: Daily journal entries with search and export. Key Features: - Entry with date, title, mood, content - Search by date range or keyword - Export to text/Markdown - Daily prompts

docs.title: Project 07: Password Manager
docs.text: Concept: Secure password storage with master password. Key Features: - Master password authentication - Generate secure passwords - Store/retrieve passwords - Copy to clipboard (optional)

docs.title: Project 08: URL Shortener
docs.text: Concept: Map long URLs to short codes. Key Features: - Generate unique short codes - Store in JSON/SQLite - Redirect/resolve URLs - Click tracking

docs.title: Project 09: Chat Server (CLI)
docs.text: Concept: Multi-client chat server with rooms. Key Features: - TCP socket server - Multiple clients via threading - Chat rooms/nicknames - Private messaging

docs.title: Project 10: Static Site Generator
docs.text: Concept: Convert Markdown to HTML website. Key Features: - Parse Markdown files - Apply HTML templates - Generate navigation - Copy static assets

docs.title: Project 11: Tic-Tac-Toe AI
docs.text: Concept: Unbeatable Tic-Tac-Toe using minimax. Key Features: - Human vs AI - AI vs AI - Minimax algorithm with alpha-beta - Difficulty levels

docs.title: 1. CLI Progress Tracker
docs.text:
File: tools/progress_tracker.py

Track completed topics and exercises: 

# Mark a topic as complete
python tools/progress_tracker.py --complete 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types

# Show current progress
python tools/progress_tracker.py --status

# Show detailed breakdown
python tools/progress_tracker.py --details

# Reset progress
python tools/progress_tracker.py --reset

Implementation: - Store progress in JSON file (.progress.json) - Parse PROGRESS.md for structure - Display progress bars and statistics

docs.title: 2. Interactive Quiz Runner
docs.text:
File: tools/run_quiz.py

Run quizzes from the command line: 

# Run a specific quiz
python tools/run_quiz.py 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types

# Run random questions from a module
python tools/run_quiz.py 01_foundations --random 10

# Run all quizzes
python tools/run_quiz.py --all

Implementation: - Parse quiz.md files - Interactive CLI with input validation - Score tracking and feedback - Show correct answers after completion

docs.title: 3. Exercise Validator
docs.text:
File: tools/check_exercise.py

Validate exercises without revealing solutions: 

# Check a specific exercise file
python tools/check_exercise.py Exercises/beginner/01_variables_and_types.py

# Check all exercises in a directory
python tools/check_exercise.py Exercises/beginner/

# Show hints for failed tests
python tools/check_exercise.py exercises.py --hints

Implementation: - Run exercise code in isolated environment - Check outputs against expected results - Provide hints without showing solutions - Track which exercises pass/fail

docs.title: 4. Learning Path Generator
docs.text:
File: tools/generate_path.py

Generate personalized learning paths: 

# Generate path for web development goal
python tools/generate_path.py --goal web-dev --hours 10 --weeks 12

# Generate path for data analysis
python tools/generate_path.py --goal data --hours 5 --weeks 20

# Show available goals
python tools/generate_path.py --list-goals

Implementation: - Define goal templates (web-dev, data, backend, general) - Calculate weekly schedules - Output Markdown roadmap - Consider prerequisites

docs.title: 5. Repository Statistics
docs.text:
File: tools/repo_stats.py

Generate repository statistics: 

# Show all stats
python tools/repo_stats.py

# Module coverage
python tools/repo_stats.py --coverage

# Code metrics
python tools/repo_stats.py --metrics

Metrics to track: - Lines of code by module - Number of exercises - Quiz questions count - Completion percentage - Most/least covered topics

docs.title: 🗺️ VibeLearning Roadmap
docs.text: Your guided learning path from beginner to confident programmer

docs.title: How to Use This Roadmap
docs.text:
Each module includes: - ⏱️ Estimated Time — How long to complete - 📋 Prerequisites — What you should know first - 🎯 Level — Difficulty rating (⭐ to ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐)

Tip: Don't rush! Understanding beats completing.

docs.title: 00 - Getting Started
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 1-2 hours None ⭐

What you'll learn: - Setting up Python on your system - Choosing and configuring a code editor - Running your first Python program - How to navigate this repository

docs.title: 01 - Foundations
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 8-10 hours Module 00 ⭐

What you'll learn: - Variables and data types - Operators (arithmetic, comparison, logical) - Control flow (if/elif/else) - Loops (for, while) - Writing functions - Input and output

docs.title: 02 - Data Structures
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 12-15 hours Module 01 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Lists and arrays - String manipulation - Dictionaries and maps - Sets and tuples - Stacks and queues - Linked lists, trees, and graphs - Hash tables

docs.title: 03 - Algorithms
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 15-20 hours Modules 01, 02 ⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Searching algorithms (linear, binary) - Sorting algorithms (bubble, quick, merge) - Recursion and recursive thinking - Dynamic programming basics - Greedy algorithms - Divide and conquer - Graph traversal (BFS, DFS)

docs.title: 04 - OOP Concepts
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 10-12 hours Modules 01-02 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Classes and objects - Encapsulation - Inheritance - Polymorphism - Abstraction - Composition vs inheritance - SOLID principles

docs.title: 05 - Functional Programming
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 8-10 hours Module 01 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Pure functions and side effects - Immutability - Higher-order functions - Lambda expressions - Map, filter, reduce - Closures - Decorators

docs.title: 06 - Software Design
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 6-8 hours Modules 01, 04, 05 ⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) - KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid) - YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) - Separation of concerns - Coupling and cohesion - Recognizing code smells - Refactoring techniques

docs.title: 07 - Design Patterns
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 10-12 hours Modules 04, 06 ⭐⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Creational patterns (Singleton, Factory, Builder) - Structural patterns (Adapter, Decorator, Facade) - Behavioral patterns (Observer, Strategy, Command)

docs.title: 08 - Error Handling
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 4-6 hours Module 01 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Understanding exceptions - Try/except/finally blocks - Creating custom exceptions - Defensive programming - Logging best practices

docs.title: 09 - Testing
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 8-10 hours Modules 01, 05 ⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Why testing matters - Unit testing with pytest - Test-driven development (TDD) - Mocking and stubbing - Integration testing

docs.title: 10 - File & I/O
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 4-6 hours Module 01 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Reading and writing text files - Working with JSON - Parsing CSV files - Binary file operations

docs.title: 11 - Memory & Performance
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 8-10 hours Modules 02, 03 ⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - How memory works - References vs values - Time complexity analysis - Space complexity analysis - Big-O notation mastery - Optimization techniques

docs.title: 12 - Concurrency
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 10-12 hours Modules 01-05 ⭐⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Threading basics - Synchronization primitives - Async/await programming - Understanding race conditions - Avoiding deadlocks

docs.title: 13 - Modules & Packages
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 4-6 hours Module 01 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Import system - Creating your own modules - Package structure - Virtual environments - Dependency management with pip

docs.title: 14 - Debugging
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 4-6 hours Modules 01, 08 ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Strategic print debugging - Using debuggers (pdb, IDE debuggers) - Reading and understanding tracebacks - Common bug patterns

docs.title: 15 - Version Control
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 6-8 hours None ⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Git fundamentals - Branching strategies - Merging and conflict resolution - Collaborative workflows

docs.title: 16 - Essential Libraries
docs.text:
⏱️ Time 📋 Prerequisites 🎯 Level 8-10 hours Modules 01-10 ⭐⭐⭐

What you'll learn: - Collections module (Counter, defaultdict, namedtuple, deque) - Datetime manipulation and timezones - Itertools for efficient iteration - Functools (partial, lru_cache, reduce) - Pathlib for filesystem operations - Regular expressions for pattern matching - Advanced JSON and CSV handling - Hashing and secure random generation

docs.text: Practice problems organized by difficulty: - Beginner — Reinforce foundations - Intermediate — Apply multiple concepts - Advanced — Challenge yourself

docs.title: 🚀 Module 00: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to VibeLearning! This module will help you set up your environment and understand how to use this repository effectively.

docs.title: What's in This Module
docs.text: File Description 01_python_setup.md Installing Python on your system 02_running_code.md Different ways to run Python code 03_using_this_repo.md How to navigate and use VibeLearning

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • ✅ Have Python installed and working on your computer
  • ✅ Know how to run Python programs
  • ✅ Understand how to navigate this repository
  • ✅ Be ready to start learning!

docs.title: Time Estimate
docs.text: ⏱️ 1-2 hours to complete this module

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A computer (Windows, macOS, or Linux)
  • Internet connection for downloading Python
  • Curiosity and enthusiasm! 🎉

docs.title: Let's Begin!
docs.text: Start with 01_python_setup.md to install Python.

docs.title: 🐍 Python Setup Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you install Python on your computer.

docs.title: Step 1: Check if Python is Already Installed
docs.text:
Open your terminal/command prompt and type:

python --version

or

python3 --version

If you see something like Python 3.11.5, you're already set! Skip to 02_running_code.md.

docs.title: 🪟 Windows
docs.text:
1. Go to python.org/downloads
  2. Click the big yellow "Download Python 3.x.x" button
  3. Run the installer
  4. IMPORTANT: Check the box that says "Add Python to PATH"
  5. Click "Install Now"

docs.title: 🍎 macOS
docs.text:
Option A: Official Installer 1. Go to python.org/downloads 2. Download the macOS installer 3. Run the .pkg file and follow the prompts

Option B: Using Homebrew (recommended if you have Homebrew) 

brew install python

docs.title: 🐧 Linux
docs.text:
Most Linux distributions come with Python. If not:

Ubuntu/Debian: 

sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3 python3-pip

Fedora: 

sudo dnf install python3 python3-pip

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Open a new terminal window and run:

python --version

You should see: 

Python 3.x.x

Also verify pip (Python's package manager): 

pip --version

docs.title: Step 4: Choose a Code Editor
docs.text: You'll need a place to write your code. Here are great options:

docs.title: VS Code (Recommended for Beginners)
docs.text:
• Free and powerful
  • Great Python support
  • Download: code.visualstudio.com
  • Install the "Python" extension after installing VS Code

docs.title: PyCharm Community Edition
docs.text:
• Free version available
  • Specifically designed for Python
  • Download: jetbrains.com/pycharm

docs.title: Other Options
docs.text:
• Sublime Text — Lightweight and fast
  • Atom — Free and customizable
  • IDLE — Comes with Python (basic but sufficient to start)

docs.title: Step 5: Test Your Setup
docs.text:
Create a file called hello.py with this content:

print("Hello, VibeLearning! 🚀")
print("Python is working correctly!")

Run it: 

python hello.py

You should see: 

Hello, VibeLearning! 🚀
Python is working correctly!

docs.title: "python" command not found
docs.text:
• Windows: Reinstall Python and make sure "Add to PATH" is checked
  • macOS/Linux: Try python3 instead of python

docs.title: Permission denied
docs.text:
• macOS/Linux: You may need sudo for installation
  • Windows: Run the installer as Administrator

docs.title: Old Python version
docs.text:
• Make sure you downloaded Python 3.x (not Python 2.x)
  • Python 2 is outdated and not recommended

docs.title: ✅ Ready?
docs.text: Once Python is installed and working, move on to 02_running_code.md to learn different ways to run your code!

docs.title: ▶️ Running Python Code
docs.text: There are several ways to run Python code. Understanding them will make your learning journey smoother.

docs.title: Method 1: Running a Python File
docs.text: This is the most common way to run Python programs.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Create a file with a .py extension (e.g., my_program.py)
  2. Write your Python code in the file
  3. Open terminal/command prompt
  4. Navigate to the file's directory
  5. Run: python my_program.py

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
Create greet.py: 

name = "World"
print(f"Hello, {name}!")

Run it: 

python greet.py

Output: 

Hello, World!

docs.title: Method 2: Python Interactive Mode (REPL)
docs.text:
REPL = Read-Evaluate-Print-Loop

Great for quick experiments and testing small pieces of code.

docs.title: How to Start:
docs.text:
python

You'll see: 

Python 3.x.x (...)
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>>

docs.title: Try It:
docs.text:
>>> 2 + 2
4
>>> print("Hello!")
Hello!
>>> name = "Python"
>>> f"I love {name}"
'I love Python'
>>> exit()  # To leave

docs.title: Method 3: Running Code in Your Editor
docs.text: Most modern editors can run Python directly.

docs.title: VS Code:
docs.text:
1. Open your .py file
  2. Click the ▶️ (Play) button in the top-right
  3. Or press Ctrl+F5 (Windows) / Cmd+F5 (Mac)

docs.title: PyCharm:
docs.text:
1. Open your .py file
  2. Right-click → "Run 'filename'"
  3. Or press Shift+F10

docs.title: Method 4: Jupyter Notebooks
docs.text: Interactive notebooks that mix code, output, and documentation.

docs.title: Install:
docs.text: pip install jupyter

docs.title: Start:
docs.text:
jupyter notebook

This opens in your browser where you can create .ipynb files.

Great for: - Data science - Learning (see code + results together) - Experimentation

docs.title: Which Method Should You Use?
docs.text: Situation Recommended Method Learning concepts REPL or Jupyter Writing real programs Python files + Editor Quick calculations REPL Sharing code Python files Data analysis Jupyter Notebooks

docs.title: Common Commands Reference
docs.text:
# Run a Python file
python filename.py

# Start interactive mode
python

# Check Python version
python --version

# Install a package
pip install package_name

# List installed packages
pip list

docs.title: 💡 Tips
docs.text:
1. Always save your file before running it
  2. Use meaningful file names like calculator.py not test1.py
  3. Don't name your files after Python modules (e.g., don't create random.py)
  4. Read error messages — they usually tell you what's wrong

docs.title: ✅ Next Step
docs.text: Now that you know how to run Python code, learn how to use this repository effectively!

docs.title: 📖 Using This Repository
docs.text: This guide explains how VibeLearning is organized and how to get the most out of it.

docs.text:
VibeLearning/

docs.title: How Each Concept Is Organized
docs.text:
Every concept folder follows the same structure:

concept_name/
├── README.md      # 📚 Theory and explanations
├── examples.py    # 💻 Runnable code examples
├── exercises.py   # ✏️ Practice problems
└── quiz.md        # ❓ Test your understanding

docs.title: README.md
docs.text:
• What: Theory, explanations, real-world analogies
  • How to use: Read through first to understand the concept
  • Goal: Build mental model before coding

docs.title: examples.py
docs.text:
• What: Working code demonstrating the concept
  • How to use: Run the file, then read through the code
  • Goal: See the concept in action
# How to run examples
cd 01_foundations/01_variables_and_types
python examples.py

docs.title: exercises.py
docs.text:
• What: Practice problems with solutions
  • How to use: Try solving before looking at answers
  • Goal: Reinforce learning through practice

docs.title: quiz.md
docs.text:
• What: Questions to test your understanding
  • How to use: Answer without looking back at notes
  • Goal: Identify gaps in knowledge

docs.title: Recommended Learning Workflow
docs.text:
For each concept:

1. 📚 Read README.md
        ↓
2. 💻 Run and study examples.py
        ↓
3. ✏️ Attempt exercises.py
        ↓
4. ❓ Take the quiz.md
        ↓
5. 🔄 Review if needed

docs.title: Time Per Concept
docs.text:
• Simple concepts: 30-60 minutes
  • Medium concepts: 1-2 hours
  • Complex concepts: 2-4 hours

docs.title: Do's ✅
docs.text: Tip Why Type code yourself Muscle memory matters Run examples before reading See behavior first, then understand Modify examples Experimenting deepens understanding Make mistakes Errors are learning opportunities Take breaks Your brain consolidates during rest Teach others Best way to solidify knowledge

docs.title: Don'ts ❌
docs.text: Avoid Why Copy-pasting code You won't remember it Rushing through Understanding beats speed Skipping exercises Practice makes permanent Ignoring errors They teach you how things work

docs.text:

docs.title: If Code Doesn't Run:
docs.text:
1. Check for typos
  2. Make sure you're in the right directory
  3. Verify Python is installed correctly
  4. Read the error message carefully

docs.title: 📦 Variables and Types
docs.text: Variables are containers for storing data. Types define what kind of data you're storing.

docs.title: What is a Variable?
docs.text:
Think of a variable as a labeled box where you can store something.

# Creating a variable is like putting something in a labeled box
message = "Hello, World!"
#  ↑          ↑
# label    contents

The = sign is the assignment operator — it puts the value on the right into the variable on the left.

docs.title: ✅ Valid variable names:
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
age = 25
user_name = "bob123"
firstName = "John"
_private = "hidden"
counter2 = 0

docs.title: ❌ Invalid variable names:
docs.text:
2nd_place = "silver"    # Can't start with a number
user-name = "bob"       # No hyphens allowed
my name = "Alice"       # No spaces allowed
class = "Python"        # Can't use reserved words

docs.title: 💡 Naming Conventions:
docs.text:
# Python style (snake_case) - RECOMMENDED
user_name = "alice"
total_count = 42
is_valid = True

# Other styles you'll see (less common in Python)
userName = "alice"      # camelCase
UserName = "alice"      # PascalCase

docs.title: Basic Data Types
docs.text: Python has several built-in types:

docs.title: 1. Strings (str) — Text
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
greeting = 'Hello!'  # Single or double quotes work
long_text = """This is a
multiline string"""

# String operations
full_name = "Alice" + " " + "Smith"  # Concatenation
repeated = "Ha" * 3  # "HaHaHa"
length = len(name)   # 5

docs.title: 2. Integers (int) — Whole Numbers
docs.text:
age = 25
temperature = -10
population = 1_000_000  # Underscores for readability

# Integer operations
total = 10 + 5    # 15
diff = 10 - 5     # 5
product = 10 * 5  # 50

docs.title: 3. Floats (float) — Decimal Numbers
docs.text:
height = 1.75
pi = 3.14159
temperature = -40.0

# Float operations
half = 10 / 4     # 2.5 (always returns float)
result = 3.14 * 2 # 6.28

docs.title: 4. Booleans (bool) — True/False
docs.text:
is_student = True
has_license = False

# Boolean operations
can_drive = has_license and age >= 16
is_teenager = age >= 13 and age <= 19

docs.title: 5. None — Absence of Value
docs.text:
result = None  # No value assigned yet

# Check for None
if result is None:
    print("No result yet")

docs.title: Check type with type():
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 1.75
is_student = True

print(type(name))      # <class 'str'>
print(type(age))       # <class 'int'>
print(type(height))    # <class 'float'>
print(type(is_student)) # <class 'bool'>

docs.title: Convert between types:
docs.text:
# String to integer
age_str = "25"
age = int(age_str)  # 25 (now an integer)

# Integer to string
count = 42
count_str = str(count)  # "42"

# String to float
price_str = "19.99"
price = float(price_str)  # 19.99

# Float to integer (truncates!)
pi = 3.14159
whole = int(pi)  # 3 (not rounded, just truncated)

docs.title: Dynamic Typing
docs.text:
Python is dynamically typed — variables can change type:

x = 10        # x is an integer
print(type(x))  # <class 'int'>

x = "hello"   # Now x is a string!
print(type(x))  # <class 'str'>

x = [1, 2, 3] # Now x is a list!
print(type(x))  # <class 'list'>

⚠️ Note: Just because you can change types doesn't mean you should. It can make code confusing.

docs.title: 1. Using before assigning:
docs.text:
print(username)  # ❌ NameError: 'username' is not defined
username = "alice"

docs.title: 2. Wrong type operations:
docs.text:
age = "25"
next_year = age + 1  # ❌ TypeError: can't add string and int
next_year = int(age) + 1  # ✅ Convert first

docs.title: 3. Case sensitivity:
docs.text:
Name = "Alice"
print(name)  # ❌ NameError: 'name' is not defined
print(Name)  # ✅ Correct

docs.text:

name = "Alice"           # String

# Checking type

int("25")               # 25

bool(1)                 # True
bool(0)                 # False

docs.title: 📝 Variables and Types - Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding! Try to answer without looking back.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What type is the variable x after this code runs? 

x = "42"

A) int B) float C) str D) bool

Click for answer **C) str** Even though it looks like a number, the quotes make it a string.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What will this code print? 

x = 10
y = 3
print(x / y)

A) 3 B) 3.0 C) 3.333... D) Error

Click for answer **C) 3.333...** Regular division (`/`) always returns a float. For integer division, use `//`.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which variable name is INVALID?

A) my_variable B) _count C) 2nd_place D) firstName

Click for answer **C) 2nd_place** Variable names cannot start with a number.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What will int(3.9) return?

A) 3 B) 4 C) 3.9 D) Error

Click for answer **A) 3** `int()` truncates (cuts off) the decimal part. It does NOT round.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What is printed? 

a = "Hello"
b = a
a = "World"
print(b)

A) Hello B) World C) HelloWorld D) Error

Click for answer **A) Hello** When we assign `a = "World"`, we're changing what `a` points to. `b` still points to the original string "Hello".

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
What does this code print? 

x = None
if x:
    print("True")
else:
    print("False")

A) True B) False C) None D) Error

Click for answer **B) False** `None` is "falsy" in Python, so it evaluates to `False` in a boolean context.

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
What is the result of "Ha" * 3?

A) "Ha3" B) "HaHaHa" C) Error D) 6

Click for answer **B) "HaHaHa"** Multiplying a string by an integer repeats the string.

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
What does type(True) return?

A) <class 'int'> B) <class 'str'> C) <class 'bool'> D) <class 'true'>

Click for answer **C) ``** `True` and `False` are boolean values.

docs.title: Bonus Question
docs.text:
What will this print? 

a, b = 1, 2
a, b = b, a + b
print(a, b)

A) 2, 3 B) 1, 2 C) 2, 1 D) 3, 2

Click for answer **A) 2, 3** Python evaluates the right side first: `b` is 2, `a + b` is 3. Then assigns: `a = 2`, `b = 3`.

docs.title: ➕ Operators
docs.text: Operators are symbols that perform operations on values. Think of them as verbs in the language of programming.

docs.title: Categories of Operators
docs.text: Category Purpose Examples Arithmetic Math operations +, -, *, / Comparison Compare values ==, !=, <, > Logical Combine booleans and, or, not Assignment Assign values =, +=, -= Membership Check containment in, not in Identity Check if same object is, is not

docs.title: Arithmetic Operators
docs.text:
Perform mathematical calculations.

a = 10
b = 3

# Basic operations
print(a + b)   # 13  (Addition)
print(a - b)   # 7   (Subtraction)
print(a * b)   # 30  (Multiplication)
print(a / b)   # 3.333... (Division - always float)
print(a // b)  # 3   (Floor/Integer division)
print(a % b)   # 1   (Modulo - remainder)
print(a ** b)  # 1000 (Exponentiation - power)

docs.title: Division Types
docs.text:
# Regular division (/) - always returns float
10 / 3   # 3.333...
10 / 2   # 5.0 (still a float!)

# Floor division (//) - rounds down to integer
10 // 3  # 3
-10 // 3 # -4 (rounds toward negative infinity)

# Modulo (%) - remainder after division
10 % 3   # 1 (10 = 3*3 + 1)
15 % 5   # 0 (15 = 5*3 + 0, evenly divisible)

docs.title: Order of Operations (PEMDAS)
docs.text:
# Python follows mathematical order of operations
result = 2 + 3 * 4      # 14 (not 20!)
result = (2 + 3) * 4    # 20 (parentheses first)
result = 2 ** 3 ** 2    # 512 (exponents: right to left)
result = 10 - 5 - 2     # 3 (same precedence: left to right)

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text:
Compare values and return True or False.

x = 5
y = 10

# Equality
x == y   # False (equal to)
x != y   # True  (not equal to)

# Ordering
x < y    # True  (less than)
x > y    # False (greater than)
x <= y   # True  (less than or equal)
x >= y   # False (greater than or equal)

docs.title: String Comparison
docs.text:
Strings are compared lexicographically (dictionary order):

"apple" < "banana"   # True (a comes before b)
"Apple" < "apple"    # True (uppercase before lowercase)
"10" < "9"           # True (string comparison, not numeric!)

docs.title: Chained Comparisons
docs.text:
Python allows elegant chained comparisons:

x = 5
1 < x < 10     # True  (x is between 1 and 10)
1 < x < 3      # False (x is not between 1 and 3)
1 <= x <= 10   # True  (inclusive range)

docs.title: Logical Operators
docs.text:
Combine boolean expressions.

a = True
b = False

a and b    # False (both must be True)
a or b     # True  (at least one must be True)
not a      # False (inverts the value)

docs.title: Truth Tables
docs.text:
AND: Returns True only if BOTH are True
True  and True   → True
True  and False  → False
False and True   → False
False and False  → False

OR: Returns True if AT LEAST ONE is True
True  or True    → True
True  or False   → True
False or True    → True
False or False   → False

NOT: Inverts the value
not True  → False
not False → True

docs.title: Short-Circuit Evaluation
docs.text:
Python stops evaluating as soon as the result is determined:

# With 'and': stops at first False
False and expensive_function()  # expensive_function() never runs

# With 'or': stops at first True
True or expensive_function()    # expensive_function() never runs

docs.title: Practical Examples
docs.text:
age = 25
has_license = True
has_car = False

# Can drive alone?
can_drive = age >= 16 and has_license  # True

# Has transportation?
has_transport = has_car or has_bicycle  # Depends on has_bicycle

# Is teenager?
is_teen = age >= 13 and age <= 19  # False (25 is not 13-19)
is_teen = 13 <= age <= 19          # Same thing, cleaner syntax

docs.title: Assignment Operators
docs.text:
Regular and compound assignment.

# Simple assignment
x = 10

# Compound assignment (shorthand for x = x + 5)
x += 5   # x = x + 5  → x is now 15
x -= 3   # x = x - 3  → x is now 12
x *= 2   # x = x * 2  → x is now 24
x /= 4   # x = x / 4  → x is now 6.0
x //= 2  # x = x // 2 → x is now 3.0
x **= 2  # x = x ** 2 → x is now 9.0
x %= 5   # x = x % 5  → x is now 4.0

docs.title: Membership Operators
docs.text:
Check if a value exists in a sequence.

# With strings
"a" in "cat"       # True
"x" in "cat"       # False

# With lists
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
"apple" in fruits       # True
"grape" in fruits       # False
"grape" not in fruits   # True

# With ranges
5 in range(1, 10)   # True
15 in range(1, 10)  # False

docs.title: Identity Operators
docs.text:
Check if two variables refer to the same object in memory.

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]
c = a

# Equality (==) checks if values are the same
a == b  # True (same values)
a == c  # True (same values)

# Identity (is) checks if it's the same object
a is b  # False (different objects, same values)
a is c  # True (same object!)

# None should be checked with 'is'
x = None
x is None      # ✅ Correct
x == None      # ⚠️ Works but not recommended

docs.title: Operator Precedence (Highest to Lowest)
docs.text:
Priority Operators Description 1 () Parentheses 2 ** Exponentiation 3 +x, -x, not Unary plus, minus, NOT 4 *, /, //, % Multiplication, division 5 +, - Addition, subtraction 6 <, <=, >, >=, ==, != Comparisons 7 is, is not Identity 8 in, not in Membership 9 and Logical AND 10 or Logical OR

Tip: When in doubt, use parentheses to make your intent clear!

# Confusing
result = True or False and False  # True

# Clear
result = True or (False and False)  # True (and evaluates first anyway)

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
# Arithmetic
+ - * /  // % **

# Comparison
== != < > <= >=

# Logical
and or not

# Assignment
= += -= *= /= //= **= %=

# Membership
in, not in

# Identity
is, is not

docs.title: 📝 Operators - Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of operators!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the result of 17 // 5?

A) 3.4 B) 3 C) 4 D) 2

Click for answer **B) 3** `//` is floor division. It divides and rounds down to the nearest integer.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is 17 % 5?

A) 3.4 B) 3 C) 2 D) 0

Click for answer **C) 2** `%` (modulo) gives the remainder. 17 = 5 × 3 + **2**

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does True and False or True evaluate to?

A) True B) False C) Error D) None

Click for answer **A) True** `and` has higher precedence than `or`: - `True and False` → `False` - `False or True` → `True`

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What is the result of 2 ** 3 ** 2?

A) 64 B) 512 C) 256 D) Error

Click for answer **B) 512** Exponentiation is right-associative: - First: `3 ** 2` = 9 - Then: `2 ** 9` = 512

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which expression checks if x is between 1 and 10 (inclusive)?

A) x > 1 and x < 10 B) 1 < x < 10 C) 1 <= x <= 10 D) x >= 1 or x <= 10

Click for answer **C) `1 <= x <= 10`** This is a chained comparison that includes the endpoints (1 and 10).

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
What does "3" in "12345" return?

A) True B) False C) 3 D) Error

Click for answer **A) True** The `in` operator checks if the substring "3" exists in "12345". It does!

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
Given a = [1, 2, 3] and b = [1, 2, 3], what is a is b?

A) True B) False C) [1, 2, 3] D) Error

Click for answer **B) False** `is` checks if they're the same object in memory. They have equal values (`a == b` is True), but they're different objects.

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
What is 10 / 5?

A) 2 B) 2.0 C) 2.5 D) Error

Click for answer **B) 2.0** Regular division `/` always returns a float, even when the result is a whole number.

docs.title: Question 9
docs.text:
What does x += 3 mean?

A) x = 3 B) x = x + 3 C) x + 3 D) x == x + 3

Click for answer **B) x = x + 3** `+=` is a compound assignment operator. It adds and assigns in one step.

docs.title: Question 10
docs.text:
What is not (True or False)?

A) True B) False C) None D) Error

Click for answer **B) False** - First: `True or False` → `True` - Then: `not True` → `False`

docs.title: Bonus Question
docs.text:
What does this return: "a" < "A"?

A) True B) False C) Error D) Cannot be compared

Click for answer **B) False** In ASCII, uppercase letters (A=65) come before lowercase letters (a=97). So "a" > "A".

docs.title: How did you do?
docs.text:
• 9-11 correct: Operator master! 🏆
  • 7-8 correct: Great job! Review the tricky ones.
  • 5-6 correct: Keep practicing with examples.
  • 0-4 correct: Re-read the README and run examples again.

docs.title: 🔀 Control Flow
docs.text: Control flow determines which code runs based on conditions. It's how your program makes decisions.

docs.title: What is Control Flow?
docs.text:
Without control flow, code runs line by line, top to bottom:

print("Line 1")
print("Line 2")
print("Line 3")
# Always prints all three lines

With control flow, you can make decisions:

if weather == "sunny":
    print("Go outside!")
else:
    print("Stay inside.")
# Only one message prints, depending on the condition

docs.title: The if Statement
docs.text:
The most basic form of control flow.

age = 20

if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")

docs.title: Key Points:
docs.text:
• The condition must evaluate to True or False
  • The colon (:) is required after the condition
  • The code block must be indented (usually 4 spaces)

docs.title: if-else Statement
docs.text:
Do one thing or another.

temperature = 35

if temperature > 30:
    print("It's hot!")
else:
    print("It's not too hot.")

docs.title: if-elif-else Statement
docs.text:
Multiple conditions, check one after another.

score = 85

if score >= 90:
    grade = "A"
elif score >= 80:
    grade = "B"
elif score >= 70:
    grade = "C"
elif score >= 60:
    grade = "D"
else:
    grade = "F"

print(f"Your grade is {grade}")  # B

docs.title: Key Points:
docs.text:
• elif is short for "else if"
  • Only the first matching condition runs
  • else catches everything that didn't match
  • else is optional

docs.title: Common Mistake:
docs.text:
score = 95

# ❌ Wrong: All conditions checked independently
if score >= 60:
    print("D")  # This runs!
if score >= 70:
    print("C")  # This also runs!
if score >= 80:
    print("B")  # This also runs!
if score >= 90:
    print("A")  # This also runs!

# ✅ Correct: Use elif for mutually exclusive conditions
if score >= 90:
    print("A")  # Only this runs
elif score >= 80:
    print("B")
elif score >= 70:
    print("C")
elif score >= 60:
    print("D")

docs.title: Nested Conditions
docs.text:
Conditions inside conditions.

has_ticket = True
age = 15

if has_ticket:
    if age >= 18:
        print("Welcome to the movie!")
    else:
        print("You need a guardian for this movie.")
else:
    print("Please buy a ticket first.")

docs.title: When to Nest:
docs.text:
• When one condition depends on another
  • Keep nesting shallow (2-3 levels max)
  • Consider using and / or to flatten

docs.title: Flattened Version:
docs.text:
if not has_ticket:
    print("Please buy a ticket first.")
elif age < 18:
    print("You need a guardian for this movie.")
else:
    print("Welcome to the movie!")

docs.title: Conditional Expressions (Ternary Operator)
docs.text:
A one-liner for simple if-else.

# Traditional if-else
if age >= 18:
    status = "adult"
else:
    status = "minor"

# Conditional expression (same result)
status = "adult" if age >= 18 else "minor"

docs.title: Syntax:
docs.text: value_if_true if condition else value_if_false

docs.title: Best Used For:
docs.text:
# Simple assignments
max_value = a if a > b else b

# Default values
name = username if username else "Anonymous"

# Quick formatting
print(f"You have {count} item{'s' if count != 1 else ''}")

docs.title: When NOT to Use:
docs.text:
# ❌ Too complex, hard to read
result = "A" if score >= 90 else "B" if score >= 80 else "C" if score >= 70 else "F"

# ✅ Better as regular if-elif-else
if score >= 90:
    result = "A"
elif score >= 80:
    result = "B"
# ...

docs.title: Truthy and Falsy Values
docs.text: In conditions, some values act as True or False:

docs.title: Falsy Values (evaluate to False):
docs.text:
bool(False)    # False
bool(None)     # False
bool(0)        # False
bool(0.0)      # False
bool("")       # False (empty string)
bool([])       # False (empty list)
bool({})       # False (empty dict)

docs.title: Truthy Values (evaluate to True):
docs.text:
bool(True)     # True
bool(1)        # True (any non-zero number)
bool(-1)       # True
bool("hello")  # True (non-empty string)
bool([1, 2])   # True (non-empty list)
bool({"a": 1}) # True (non-empty dict)

docs.title: Practical Use:
docs.text:
# Check if a list has items
items = []
if items:
    print(f"You have {len(items)} items")
else:
    print("Your list is empty")

# Check if a string has content
name = ""
if name:
    print(f"Hello, {name}")
else:
    print("Hello, stranger")

docs.title: Guard Clauses
docs.text:
Check for invalid cases first, return early:

def process_order(order):
    if order is None:
        return "No order provided"

    if len(order.items) == 0:
        return "Order is empty"

    if not order.is_paid:
        return "Order not paid"

    # Main logic here (only reached if all checks pass)
    return "Processing order..."

docs.title: Default Values with or
docs.text:
# If username is empty/None, use "Guest"
display_name = username or "Guest"

docs.title: Safe Access with and
docs.text:
# Only access .name if user exists
name = user and user.name

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
# Basic if
if condition:
    # code

# If-else
if condition:
    # code if true
else:
    # code if false

# If-elif-else
if condition1:
    # code
elif condition2:
    # code
else:
    # code

# Conditional expression
value = true_val if condition else false_val

# Truthy/Falsy shorthand
if my_list:  # same as: if len(my_list) > 0
    pass

if name:  # same as: if name != ""
    pass

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Practice with examples.py, then try exercises.py!

docs.title: 📝 Control Flow - Quiz
docs.text: Test your decision-making skills!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What will this code print? 

x = 5
if x > 10:
    print("A")
elif x > 3:
    print("B")
elif x > 1:
    print("C")
else:
    print("D")

A) A B) B C) C D) B and C

Click for answer **B) B** Only the first matching condition (`x > 3`) executes. Even though `x > 1` is also true, `elif` stops after the first match.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does if not False: evaluate to?

A) True B) False C) Error D) None

Click for answer **A) True** `not False` equals `True`, so the condition is met.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What will this print? 

value = ""
if value:
    print("truthy")
else:
    print("falsy")

A) truthy B) falsy C) "" D) Error

Click for answer **B) falsy** An empty string is a falsy value in Python.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What is the output? 

age = 20
status = "adult" if age >= 18 else "minor"
print(status)

A) adult B) minor C) True D) Error

Click for answer **A) adult** This is a conditional expression (ternary). Since `20 >= 18` is True, "adult" is assigned.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What will this print? 

x = 0
if x:
    print("yes")

A) yes B) no C) 0 D) Nothing (no output)

Click for answer **D) Nothing (no output)** `0` is falsy, so the condition is False and the block doesn't execute.

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
Which is a valid way to check if x is between 5 and 10 (inclusive)?

A) if x >= 5 and <= 10: B) if 5 <= x <= 10: C) if x in range(5, 10): D) if 5 < x < 10:

Click for answer **B) `if 5 <= x <= 10:`** A) is invalid syntax. C) excludes 10. D) excludes both 5 and 10.

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
What does this code print? 

a = True
b = False
if a and b:
    print("both")
elif a or b:
    print("at least one")
else:
    print("neither")

A) both B) at least one C) neither D) Error

Click for answer **B) at least one** `a and b` is False (both must be True). `a or b` is True (at least one is True).

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
What is printed? 

x = None
result = x or "default"
print(result)

A) None B) default C) True D) Error

Click for answer **B) default** `None` is falsy, so `or` returns the second value "default".

docs.title: Question 9
docs.text:
What happens here? 

if True:
print("hello")

A) Prints "hello" B) Prints nothing C) IndentationError D) SyntaxError

Click for answer **C) IndentationError** The code block under `if` must be indented.

docs.title: Question 10
docs.text:
What will this print? 

num = 15
if num % 3 == 0:
    print("Fizz", end="")
if num % 5 == 0:
    print("Buzz", end="")
print()

A) Fizz B) Buzz C) FizzBuzz D) 15

Click for answer **C) FizzBuzz** These are two separate `if` statements (not elif), so both conditions are checked independently.

  • 7-8 correct: Great work! Review the ones you missed.

  • 0-4 correct: Re-read the README and run examples.

docs.title: 🔁 Loops
docs.text: Loops let you repeat code. Instead of writing the same thing many times, write it once and loop.

docs.title: Why Loops?
docs.text:
Without loops: 

print("Hello!")
print("Hello!")
print("Hello!")
print("Hello!")
print("Hello!")

With loops: 

for i in range(5):
    print("Hello!")

docs.title: For Loops
docs.text: Use for when you know how many times to repeat, or when iterating over a collection.

docs.title: Basic Syntax:
docs.text:
for item in iterable:
    # do something with item

docs.title: Iterating Over Range:
docs.text:
# range(5) = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

# range(start, stop) = start to stop-1
for i in range(2, 6):
    print(i)  # 2, 3, 4, 5

# range(start, stop, step)
for i in range(0, 10, 2):
    print(i)  # 0, 2, 4, 6, 8

# Counting backwards
for i in range(5, 0, -1):
    print(i)  # 5, 4, 3, 2, 1

docs.title: Iterating Over Collections:
docs.text:
# List
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

# String (character by character)
for char in "Hello":
    print(char)

# Dictionary
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
for key in person:
    print(f"{key}: {person[key]}")

# Dictionary with items()
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

docs.title: enumerate() - Get Index Too:
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

# Without enumerate
for i in range(len(fruits)):
    print(f"{i}: {fruits[i]}")

# With enumerate (cleaner!)
for i, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(f"{i}: {fruit}")

# Start from different index
for i, fruit in enumerate(fruits, start=1):
    print(f"{i}: {fruit}")  # 1, 2, 3

docs.title: While Loops
docs.text: Use while when you don't know how many iterations needed, or until a condition becomes false.

docs.title: Basic Syntax:
docs.text:
while condition:
    # do something
    # (make sure condition eventually becomes False!)

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
# Count to 5
count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

# User input loop
password = ""
while password != "secret":
    password = input("Enter password: ")
print("Access granted!")

# Game loop pattern
running = True
while running:
    action = input("Enter action (q to quit): ")
    if action == "q":
        running = False

docs.title: ⚠️ Infinite Loops:
docs.text:
# This never stops! (Ctrl+C to break)
while True:
    print("Forever...")

# Accidental infinite loop (forgot to update condition)
x = 0
while x < 5:
    print(x)
    # Forgot: x += 1

docs.title: break - Exit the Loop Immediately:
docs.text:
# Find first even number
numbers = [1, 3, 5, 8, 9, 10]
for num in numbers:
    if num % 2 == 0:
        print(f"First even: {num}")
        break  # Exit the loop

docs.title: continue - Skip to Next Iteration:
docs.text:
# Print only odd numbers
for i in range(10):
    if i % 2 == 0:
        continue  # Skip even numbers
    print(i)  # Only odd numbers print

docs.title: else Clause (runs if loop completes normally):
docs.text:
# Search for a value
for num in [1, 3, 5, 7]:
    if num == 4:
        print("Found 4!")
        break
else:
    print("4 not found")  # This runs because no break occurred

docs.title: Nested Loops
docs.text:
Loops inside loops:

# Multiplication table
for i in range(1, 4):
    for j in range(1, 4):
        print(f"{i} × {j} = {i * j}")
    print("---")

# Output:
# 1 × 1 = 1
# 1 × 2 = 2
# 1 × 3 = 3
# ---
# 2 × 1 = 2
# ...

docs.title: Breaking Out of Nested Loops:
docs.text:
# break only exits the innermost loop
for i in range(3):
    for j in range(3):
        if j == 1:
            break  # Only breaks inner loop
        print(f"i={i}, j={j}")

# To break outer loop, use a flag
found = False
for i in range(3):
    for j in range(3):
        if some_condition:
            found = True
            break
    if found:
        break

docs.title: Sum/Accumulator:
docs.text:
total = 0
for num in [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
    total += num
print(f"Sum: {total}")  # 15

docs.title: Counter:
docs.text:
count = 0
for char in "hello world":
    if char == "l":
        count += 1
print(f"Found 'l' {count} times")  # 3

docs.title: Building a List:
docs.text:
squares = []
for i in range(1, 6):
    squares.append(i ** 2)
print(squares)  # [1, 4, 9, 16, 25]

docs.title: Finding Max/Min:
docs.text:
numbers = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9, 2]

max_val = numbers[0]
for num in numbers:
    if num > max_val:
        max_val = num
print(f"Max: {max_val}")  # 9

docs.title: Search:
docs.text:
target = 4
found = False
for num in [1, 3, 4, 7, 9]:
    if num == target:
        found = True
        break

if found:
    print(f"Found {target}!")
else:
    print(f"{target} not found")

docs.title: List Comprehensions (Pythonic Loops)
docs.text:
A concise way to create lists:

# Traditional for loop
squares = []
for i in range(1, 6):
    squares.append(i ** 2)

# List comprehension (same result)
squares = [i ** 2 for i in range(1, 6)]

# With condition
evens = [i for i in range(10) if i % 2 == 0]

# With transformation
words = ["hello", "world"]
upper = [w.upper() for w in words]

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
# For loop
for item in iterable:
    pass

# While loop
while condition:
    pass

# Range variations
range(5)          # 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
range(2, 5)       # 2, 3, 4
range(0, 10, 2)   # 0, 2, 4, 6, 8

# Loop control
break     # Exit loop
continue  # Skip to next iteration

# Useful functions
enumerate(list)   # Get index and value
zip(list1, list2) # Pair up elements

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Practice with examples.py, then try exercises.py!

docs.title: 📝 Loops - Quiz
docs.text: Test your loop knowledge!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What will range(3) produce?

A) 1, 2, 3 B) 0, 1, 2 C) 0, 1, 2, 3 D) 1, 2

Click for answer **B) 0, 1, 2** `range(n)` produces numbers from 0 to n-1.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this print? 

for i in range(5, 2, -1):
    print(i, end=" ")

A) 5 4 3 2 B) 5 4 3 C) 2 3 4 5 D) 3 4 5

Click for answer **B) 5 4 3** Starts at 5, stops before 2, steps by -1. So: 5, 4, 3.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does break do?

A) Pauses the loop B) Exits the loop immediately C) Skips to the next iteration D) Restarts the loop

Click for answer **B) Exits the loop immediately** `break` completely stops the loop execution.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What will this print? 

for i in range(3):
    pass
else:
    print("done")

A) done B) Nothing C) Error D) 0 1 2 done

Click for answer **A) done** The `else` clause runs when the loop completes normally (no `break`).

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What does continue do?

A) Exits the loop B) Restarts the loop from the beginning C) Skips to the next iteration D) Continues after the loop

Click for answer **C) Skips to the next iteration** `continue` jumps to the next loop iteration, skipping remaining code in the current iteration.

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
What will this print? 

i = 0
while i < 3:
    print(i)

A) 0 1 2 B) 0 0 0... (infinite) C) Nothing D) Error

Click for answer **B) 0 0 0... (infinite)** `i` is never incremented, so `i < 3` is always True. This is an infinite loop.

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
What is the output? 

nums = [1, 2, 3]
for i, n in enumerate(nums, start=1):
    print(i, end=" ")

A) 0 1 2 B) 1 2 3 C) 1 2 3 4 D) 0 1 2 3

Click for answer **B) 1 2 3** `enumerate(nums, start=1)` produces indices starting at 1.

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
Which creates [0, 1, 4, 9, 16]?

A) [i ** 2 for i in range(5)] B) [i ** 2 for i in range(1, 5)] C) [i ** 2 for i in (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)] D) [i * 2 for i in range(5)]

Click for answer **A) `[i ** 2 for i in range(5)]`** 0², 1², 2², 3², 4² = 0, 1, 4, 9, 16

docs.title: Question 9
docs.text:
What happens when break is inside a nested loop?

A) Both loops exit B) Only the innermost loop exits C) Only the outermost loop exits D) Error

Click for answer **B) Only the innermost loop exits** `break` only affects the loop it's directly inside.

docs.title: Question 10
docs.text:
How many times does this loop run? 

for i in range(10, 10):
    print("Hello")

A) 10 times B) 1 time C) 0 times D) Infinite

Click for answer **C) 0 times** `range(10, 10)` is empty because start equals stop.

docs.text:

  • 7-8 correct: Great looping skills!
  • 5-6 correct: Good, keep practicing.
  • 0-4 correct: Review the examples again.

docs.title: 🔧 Functions Basics
docs.text: Functions are reusable blocks of code. Write once, use many times.

docs.title: Why Functions?
docs.text:
Without functions: 

# Calculate area of rectangle 1
length1 = 5
width1 = 3
area1 = length1 * width1
print(f"Area: {area1}")

# Calculate area of rectangle 2 (copy-paste, error-prone!)
length2 = 8
width2 = 4
area2 = length2 * width2
print(f"Area: {area2}")

With functions: 

def calculate_area(length, width):
    return length * width

area1 = calculate_area(5, 3)
area2 = calculate_area(8, 4)

docs.title: Defining Functions
docs.text:
Basic syntax: 

def function_name(parameters):
    """Docstring: describes what the function does"""
    # Function body
    return result  # Optional

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
# No parameters, no return
def say_hello():
    print("Hello!")

# With parameters, with return
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

# With docstring
def greet(name):
    """Greet a person by name."""
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

docs.title: Calling Functions
docs.text:
# Define
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

# Call
message = greet("Alice")  # "Hello, Alice!"
print(greet("Bob"))       # Prints: Hello, Bob!

# Can call multiple times
for person in ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]:
    print(greet(person))

docs.title: Parameters vs Arguments
docs.text:
• Parameters: Variables in the function definition
  • Arguments: Actual values passed when calling
def add(a, b):     # a and b are PARAMETERS
    return a + b

result = add(5, 3)  # 5 and 3 are ARGUMENTS

docs.title: Single Return:
docs.text:
def square(n):
    return n ** 2

result = square(5)  # 25

docs.title: Multiple Returns:
docs.text:
def divide_with_remainder(a, b):
    quotient = a // b
    remainder = a % b
    return quotient, remainder  # Returns a tuple

q, r = divide_with_remainder(17, 5)  # q=3, r=2

docs.title: No Return (returns None):
docs.text:
def print_greeting(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")
    # No return statement

result = print_greeting("Alice")  # Prints, but...
print(result)  # None

docs.title: Early Return:
docs.text:
def get_grade(score):
    if score < 0 or score > 100:
        return "Invalid score"  # Exit early

    if score >= 90:
        return "A"
    elif score >= 80:
        return "B"
    # etc.

docs.title: Default Parameters
docs.text:
def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    return f"{greeting}, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))           # Hello, Alice!
print(greet("Alice", "Hi"))     # Hi, Alice!
print(greet("Alice", "Howdy"))  # Howdy, Alice!

docs.title: Rules for Defaults:
docs.text:
# ✅ Correct: defaults come after non-defaults
def func(required, optional="default"):
    pass

# ❌ Wrong: non-default after default
def func(optional="default", required):  # SyntaxError
    pass

docs.title: Keyword Arguments
docs.text:
Call with parameter names for clarity:

def create_user(name, age, city):
    return f"{name}, {age}, from {city}"

# Positional arguments (order matters)
create_user("Alice", 25, "NYC")

# Keyword arguments (order doesn't matter)
create_user(city="NYC", name="Alice", age=25)

# Mix (positional first, then keyword)
create_user("Alice", city="NYC", age=25)

docs.title: *args - Variable Positional Arguments:
docs.text:
def add_all(*args):
    """Add any number of arguments."""
    total = 0
    for num in args:
        total += num
    return total

add_all(1, 2)           # 3
add_all(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)  # 15

docs.title: **kwargs - Variable Keyword Arguments:
docs.text:
def print_info(**kwargs):
    """Print any key-value pairs."""
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print(f"{key}: {value}")

print_info(name="Alice", age=25, city="NYC")
# name: Alice
# age: 25
# city: NYC

docs.title: Combined:
docs.text:
def func(required, *args, default="value", **kwargs):
    print(f"Required: {required}")
    print(f"Args: {args}")
    print(f"Default: {default}")
    print(f"Kwargs: {kwargs}")

func(1, 2, 3, default="custom", extra="data")

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Variables have scope — where they can be accessed.

docs.title: Local Scope:
docs.text:
def my_function():
    x = 10  # Local to this function
    print(x)

my_function()
print(x)  # ❌ NameError: x is not defined

docs.title: Global Scope:
docs.text:
x = 10  # Global variable

def my_function():
    print(x)  # Can read global

my_function()  # Prints 10
print(x)       # Also 10

docs.title: Modifying Global (avoid if possible):
docs.text:
count = 0

def increment():
    global count  # Declare intention to modify global
    count += 1

increment()
print(count)  # 1

docs.title: Lambda Functions
docs.text:
Anonymous (unnamed) functions for simple operations:

# Regular function
def square(x):
    return x ** 2

# Lambda equivalent
square = lambda x: x ** 2

# Both work the same
print(square(5))  # 25

docs.title: Common Usage:
docs.text:
# Sorting with custom key
people = [("Alice", 25), ("Bob", 30), ("Charlie", 20)]
sorted_by_age = sorted(people, key=lambda p: p[1])

# With map/filter
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squared = list(map(lambda x: x ** 2, numbers))
evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, numbers))

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
Document your functions:

def calculate_bmi(weight, height):
    """
    Calculate Body Mass Index.

    Args:
        weight: Weight in kilograms
        height: Height in meters

    Returns:
        BMI as a float

    Example:
        >>> calculate_bmi(70, 1.75)
        22.86
    """
    return weight / (height ** 2)

# Access docstring
print(calculate_bmi.__doc__)
help(calculate_bmi)

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
# Basic function
def function_name(param1, param2):
    return result

# Default parameter
def func(param="default"):
    pass

# Variable args
def func(*args, **kwargs):
    pass

# Lambda
lambda x: x * 2

# Docstring
def func():
    """Description of function."""
    pass

docs.text: Practice with examples.py, then try exercises.py!

docs.title: 📝 Functions Basics - Quiz
docs.text: Test your function knowledge!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does def stand for?

A) Default B) Define C) Defer D) Defend

Click for answer **B) Define** `def` is short for "define" - it defines a new function.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this function return? 

def mystery():
    x = 5

A) 5 B) x C) None D) Error

Click for answer **C) None** Functions without a `return` statement implicitly return `None`.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What's the output? 

def greet(name="World"):
    return f"Hello, {name}"

print(greet())

A) Hello, B) Hello, World C) Hello, name D) Error

Click for answer **B) Hello, World** When no argument is passed, the default value "World" is used.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What does *args do?

A) Creates a pointer B) Multiplies arguments C) Collects variable positional arguments D) Makes arguments optional

Click for answer **C) Collects variable positional arguments** `*args` collects any number of positional arguments into a tuple.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What's the output? 

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(b=5, a=3)
print(result)

A) Error B) 8 C) 53 D) 35

Click for answer **B) 8** Keyword arguments can be in any order. `a=3, b=5`, so 3 + 5 = 8.

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
What will happen? 

x = 10

def change():
    x = 20

change()
print(x)

A) 10 B) 20 C) Error D) None

Click for answer **A) 10** The `x = 20` inside the function creates a local variable. The global `x` remains unchanged.

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
Which is a valid lambda?

A) lambda: x * 2 B) lambda x: x * 2 C) def lambda(x): return x * 2 D) lambda x: return x * 2

Click for answer **B) `lambda x: x * 2`** Lambda syntax: `lambda parameters: expression`. No `return` keyword needed.

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
What's returned? 

def split_name(full_name):
    parts = full_name.split()
    return parts[0], parts[1]

first, last = split_name("John Doe")

A) "John Doe" B) ("John", "Doe") C) ["John", "Doe"] D) Error

Click for answer **B) ("John", "Doe")** Returning multiple values separated by commas creates a tuple.

docs.title: Question 9
docs.text:
What does **kwargs capture?

A) All arguments B) Variable positional arguments C) Variable keyword arguments D) Default arguments

Click for answer **C) Variable keyword arguments** `**kwargs` collects extra keyword arguments into a dictionary.

docs.title: Question 10
docs.text:
What's wrong with this? 

def add(a=0, b):
    return a + b

A) Nothing B) Default must come after non-default C) Can't have default for first parameter D) Wrong syntax for default

Click for answer **B) Default must come after non-default** Parameters with defaults must come after parameters without defaults.

docs.title: How did you do?
docs.text:
• 9-10 correct: Function pro! 🏆
  • 7-8 correct: Strong understanding!
  • 5-6 correct: Keep practicing.
  • 0-4 correct: Review the README and examples.

docs.title: 📥 Input and Output
docs.text: How your program communicates with the outside world.

docs.title: Output: print()
docs.text: The most basic way to show something to the user.

docs.title: Basic Print:
docs.text:
print("Hello, World!")
print(42)
print(3.14)
print(True)

docs.title: Multiple Values:
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
age = 25

print("Name:", name)               # Separated by space
print("Name:", name, "Age:", age)  # Multiple items
print(name, age, sep=", ")         # Custom separator

docs.title: F-Strings (Formatted Strings):
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 1.756

print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Age: {age}, next year: {age + 1}")
print(f"Height: {height:.2f}m")  # 2 decimal places

docs.title: Formatting Options:
docs.text:
number = 42
pi = 3.14159

# Width and alignment
print(f"|{number:5}|")    # |   42| - right aligned, width 5
print(f"|{number:<5}|")   # |42   | - left aligned
print(f"|{number:^5}|")   # | 42  | - centered

# Number formatting
print(f"{pi:.2f}")        # 3.14 - 2 decimal places
print(f"{number:04}")     # 0042 - zero-padded
print(f"{1000000:,}")     # 1,000,000 - with commas

# Percentage
print(f"{0.756:.1%}")     # 75.6%

docs.title: Print Controls:
docs.text:
# No newline at end
print("Hello", end=" ")
print("World")  # Prints: Hello World

# Custom separator
print("a", "b", "c", sep="-")  # a-b-c

# Print to file (advanced)
with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
    print("Hello, file!", file=f)

docs.title: Input: input()
docs.text: Get data from the user.

docs.title: Basic Input:
docs.text:

docs.text: Test your I/O knowledge!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What's the difference between print(a, b) and print(a + b) when a="Hello" and b="World"?

A) No difference B) First prints "Hello World", second prints "HelloWorld" C) First prints "HelloWorld", second prints "Hello World" D) Second causes an error

Click for answer **B) First prints "Hello World", second prints "HelloWorld"** `print(a, b)` adds a space between arguments. `print(a + b)` concatenates directly.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does input() always return?

A) An integer B) The type of what user entered C) A string D) None

Click for answer **C) A string** `input()` always returns a string, even if the user types a number.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does f"{3.14159:.2f}" produce?

A) 3.14159 B) 3.14 C) 3.1 D) "3.14f"

Click for answer **B) 3.14** `.2f` formats the number as a float with 2 decimal places.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What does print("Hello", end="") do differently?

A) Prints nothing B) Doesn't print a newline at the end C) Prints "end" after "Hello" D) Causes an error

Click for answer **B) Doesn't print a newline at the end** `end=""` replaces the default newline with nothing.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What does f"{5:03}" produce?

A) 53 B) 005 C) 500 D) 5

Click for answer **B) 005** `:03` zero-pads the number to 3 digits.

docs.title: Question 6
docs.text:
What does \n represent in a string?

A) The letter n B) Nothing C) A newline D) A tab

Click for answer **C) A newline** `\n` is an escape sequence for newline (line break).

docs.title: Question 7
docs.text:
How do you get multiple values from one input line? 

# User types: "10 20"

A) x, y = input() B) x, y = input().split() C) x y = input() D) [x, y] = input()

Click for answer **B) `x, y = input().split()`** `split()` breaks the string at spaces, and we unpack into x and y.

docs.title: Question 8
docs.text:
What does f"{text:>10}" do?

A) Left aligns in 10 characters B) Right aligns in 10 characters C) Centers in 10 characters D) Repeats text 10 times

Click for answer **B) Right aligns in 10 characters** `>` means right align, `<` is left, `^` is center.

docs.title: Question 9
docs.text:
What does r"C: ew" print?

A) C: ew B) C: ew C) C: ew (literally) D) Error

Click for answer **A) C: ew** The `r` prefix makes it a raw string, so ` ` is not interpreted as newline.

docs.title: Question 10
docs.text:
What's the output of print(1, 2, 3, sep="-")?

A) 1 2 3 B) 1-2-3 C) 1-2-3- D) -1-2-3

Click for answer **B) 1-2-3** `sep="-"` changes the separator between printed values from space to hyphen.

docs.text: Begin with 01_lists_arrays — the most versatile built-in structure.

docs.title: 📋 Lists and Arrays
docs.text: Lists are Python's most versatile data structure — ordered, mutable collections that can hold any type of data.

docs.title: What is a List?
docs.text:
Think of a list as a numbered container where you can store multiple items in order.

# Creating a list is like making a shopping list
shopping = ["milk", "eggs", "bread"]
#              0       1       2      <- index positions

docs.title: Creating Lists
docs.text:
# Empty list
empty = []
empty = list()

# List with items
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
mixed = [1, "hello", 3.14, True]  # Different types OK!

# List from other iterables
letters = list("hello")  # ['h', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o']
nums = list(range(5))    # [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

docs.title: Indexing (Single Element)
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "date"]

# Positive indexing (from start)
print(fruits[0])   # "apple" (first)
print(fruits[1])   # "banana" (second)

# Negative indexing (from end)
print(fruits[-1])  # "date" (last)
print(fruits[-2])  # "cherry" (second to last)

docs.title: Slicing (Multiple Elements)
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "date", "elderberry"]

# [start:end] - end is exclusive!
print(fruits[1:3])   # ["banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[:3])    # ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[2:])    # ["cherry", "date", "elderberry"]
print(fruits[::2])   # ["apple", "cherry", "elderberry"] (every 2nd)
print(fruits[::-1])  # Reversed list

docs.title: Changing Elements
docs.text:
colors = ["red", "green", "blue"]
colors[1] = "yellow"  # ["red", "yellow", "blue"]

docs.title: Adding Elements
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3]

nums.append(4)        # [1, 2, 3, 4] - add to end
nums.insert(0, 0)     # [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] - insert at index
nums.extend([5, 6])   # [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] - add multiple

docs.title: Removing Elements
docs.text:
letters = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']

letters.pop()         # Removes and returns 'e'
letters.pop(0)        # Removes and returns 'a'
letters.remove('c')   # Removes first 'c' found
del letters[0]        # Delete by index
letters.clear()       # Remove all: []

docs.title: Common List Methods
docs.text: Method Description Example append(x) Add to end [1,2].append(3) → [1,2,3] insert(i, x) Insert at index [1,3].insert(1, 2) → [1,2,3] extend(list) Add multiple [1].extend([2,3]) → [1,2,3] pop(i) Remove & return [1,2,3].pop() → 3 remove(x) Remove first x [1,2,2].remove(2) → [1,2] index(x) Find position [1,2,3].index(2) → 1 count(x) Count occurrences [1,1,2].count(1) → 2 sort() Sort in place [3,1,2].sort() → [1,2,3] reverse() Reverse in place [1,2,3].reverse() → [3,2,1] copy() Shallow copy new = old.copy()

docs.title: List Comprehensions
docs.text:
A concise way to create lists:

# Traditional way
squares = []
for x in range(5):
    squares.append(x ** 2)
# [0, 1, 4, 9, 16]

# List comprehension
squares = [x ** 2 for x in range(5)]
# [0, 1, 4, 9, 16]

# With condition
evens = [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]
# [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]

# Transform strings
words = ["hello", "world"]
upper = [w.upper() for w in words]
# ["HELLO", "WORLD"]

docs.title: Nested Lists (2D Arrays)
docs.text:
# Matrix / grid
matrix = [
    [1, 2, 3],
    [4, 5, 6],
    [7, 8, 9]
]

# Access: matrix[row][column]
print(matrix[0][0])  # 1 (top-left)
print(matrix[1][2])  # 6 (row 1, column 2)

# Loop through all elements
for row in matrix:
    for item in row:
        print(item, end=" ")
# 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9

docs.title: Find min/max
docs.text:
nums = [5, 2, 8, 1, 9]
print(min(nums))  # 1
print(max(nums))  # 9
print(sum(nums))  # 25

docs.title: Check membership
docs.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print("apple" in fruits)     # True
print("grape" not in fruits) # True

docs.title: Iterate with index
docs.text:
colors = ["red", "green", "blue"]
for i, color in enumerate(colors):
    print(f"{i}: {color}")
# 0: red
# 1: green
# 2: blue

docs.title: 1. Index out of range
docs.text:
items = [1, 2, 3]
print(items[3])  # ❌ IndexError! (valid: 0, 1, 2)

docs.title: 2. Modifying while iterating
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
for n in nums:
    if n % 2 == 0:
        nums.remove(n)  # ❌ Dangerous! Skips elements

# ✅ Better: create new list
odds = [n for n in nums if n % 2 != 0]

docs.title: 3. Shallow vs deep copy
docs.text:
original = [[1, 2], [3, 4]]
shallow = original.copy()
shallow[0][0] = 99
print(original[0][0])  # 99! Inner list is shared

# ✅ Deep copy for nested structures
import copy
deep = copy.deepcopy(original)

docs.text:
Feature Python List Array (NumPy) Types Mixed allowed Single type only Speed Slower Very fast Memory More Less Use case General purpose Math/science

💡 Note: For everyday programming, Python lists are perfect. Use NumPy arrays when doing heavy numerical computing.

2 in my_list
