docs.title: 👨‍👦 Inheritance
docs.text:
Inheritance allows a class (the child or derived class) to inherit attributes and methods from another class (the parent or base class).

This promotes code reusability. Instead of rewriting logic, you extend it!

docs.title: 🧬 Basic Inheritance
docs.text:
To inherit from a class, you put the parent class name in parentheses when defining the child class.

class Animal:
    def eat(self):
        print("Munch munch...")

class Dog(Animal):  # Dog inherits from Animal
    def bark(self):
        print("Woof!")

d = Dog()
d.eat()   # Inherited from Animal!
d.bark()  # Defined in Dog

docs.title: 🦸 The super() Function
docs.text:
When you want to use the parent's method but also add something extra, you use super(). This is very common in the __init__ method.

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

class Dog(Animal):
    def __init__(self, name, breed):
        # Call the parent's __init__ to handle the name
        super().__init__(name)
        self.breed = breed

docs.title: 🔄 Overriding Methods
docs.text:
A child class can provide a different implementation for a method that is already defined in its parent class. This is called method overriding.

class Cat(Animal):
    def eat(self):
        print("The cat eats gracefully.")

c = Cat("Whiskers")
c.eat() # Output: The cat eats gracefully.

docs.title: 🌳 Multi-level Inheritance
docs.text:
You can inherit from a class that inherits from another class.

Animal -> Mammal -> Dog

docs.title: 🕸️ Multiple Inheritance
docs.text:
Python supports inheriting from multiple classes at once (less common, can be complex).

class FlyingCar(Car, Airplane):
    pass

docs.title: 🔑 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Inheritance: Creates a hierarchy (Parent -> Child).
  2. Reusability: Child classes get parent features for free.
  3. super(): Access parent methods.
  4. Overriding: Change inherited behavior in the child class.
  5. isinstance(obj, Class): Check if an object belongs to a class or its parents.

Next: Polymorphism

docs.text:

  • [ ] It inherits attributes and methods from Parent

  • [ ] It makes the Parent class private

docs.text:

  • [ ] base()
  • [ ] super()
  • [ ] self()

docs.title: 3. What is "Method Overriding"?
docs.text:
• [ ] When a child class provides a specific implementation of a method already defined in its parent class
  • [ ] When a method calls itself
  • [ ] When two methods have the same name in the same class
  • [ ] When you delete a method

docs.text:

  • [ ] If obj is an instance of MyClass or any of its subclasses
  • [ ] If obj has the same name as MyClass
  • [ ] If obj is defined in the same file as MyClass

docs.title: 🎭 Polymorphism
docs.text: Polymorphism means "many forms". In programming, it refers to the ability of different objects to respond to the same method call in their own way.

docs.title: 🦆 Duck Typing
docs.text:
Python is a dynamic language that relies on duck typing:

"If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, then it must be a duck."

We don't care about the type of the object, only if it has the method we want to call.

class Dog:
    def speak(self):
        print("Woof")

class Cat:
    def speak(self):
        print("Meow")

def make_it_speak(animal):
    # We don't care if animal is a Dog or a Cat, 
    # as long as it has a speak() method.
    animal.speak()

make_it_speak(Dog()) # Woof
make_it_speak(Cat()) # Meow

docs.title: ➕ Operator Overloading
docs.text:
Polymorphism also allows us to define how operators like +, -, *, == behave for our custom objects using "magic methods" (dunder methods).

  • __str__(self): String representation (user-friendly).
  • __add__(self, other): Behavior for +.
  • __eq__(self, other): Behavior for ==.
  • __len__(self): Behavior for len().
class Point:
    def __init__(self, x, y):
        self.x = x
        self.y = y

    def __add__(self, other):
        # Defines behavior for: point1 + point2
        return Point(self.x + other.x, self.y + other.y)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"({self.x}, {self.y})"

p1 = Point(1, 2)
p2 = Point(3, 4)
p3 = p1 + p2
print(p3) # Output: (4, 6)

docs.title: 🔑 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Polymorphism: Different objects responding to the same interface.
  2. Duck Typing: Focus on what an object can do, not what it is.
  3. Magic Methods: Special methods like __init__, __str__, __add__ that allow operator overloading.
  4. Flexibility: Makes code more generic and reusable.

Next: Abstraction

docs.title: 🌫️ Abstraction
docs.text:
Abstraction is about hiding the complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. It reduces complexity and allows the programmer to focus on interactions on a higher level.

In Python, we achieve abstraction primarily using Abstract Base Classes (ABCs).

docs.title: 🧱 Abstract Base Classes (ABCs)
docs.text:
An abstract class is a blueprint that cannot be instantiated. It is meant to be inherited by other classes.

It often contains abstract methods: methods that are declared but contain no implementation. Child classes MUST implement these methods.

To use ABCs in Python, we import from the abc module.

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

class Shape(ABC): # Inherit from ABC

    @abstractmethod
    def area(self):
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    def perimeter(self):
        pass

# s = Shape() # Error! Cannot instantiate abstract class

docs.title: 🏗️ Implementing Concrete Classes
docs.text:
Concrete classes are valid classes that inherit from the abstract class and implement all its abstract methods.

class Square(Shape):
    def __init__(self, side):
        self.side = side

    def area(self): # Must implement this
        return self.side * self.side

    def perimeter(self): # Must implement this
        return 4 * self.side

s = Square(5)
print(s.area()) # 25

docs.title: 🔌 Interfaces
docs.text: In many languages (like Java), there is a distinction between abstract class and interface. In Python, abstract Base Classes with only abstract methods act as interfaces. They define a contract that subclasses must follow.

docs.title: 🔑 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Abstraction: Hiding details, showing essentials.
  2. ABC: Abstract Base Class (from abc module).
  3. @abstractmethod: Decorator to define a method that must be implemented by children.
  4. Enforcing Contracts: ABCs ensure that all subclasses have the required methods.

Next: Composition vs Inheritance

docs.title: 1. Can you create an instance of an Abstract Base Class (ABC)?
docs.text:
• [ ] Yes, always
  • [ ] No, never
  • [ ] Only if it has no methods
  • [ ] Only if you use super()

docs.title: 2. Which module do you need to import to create an Abstract Base Class in Python?
docs.text:
• [ ] abstract
  • [ ] abc
  • [ ] interface
  • [ ] base

docs.title: 3. What decorator is used to declare an abstract method?
docs.text:
• [ ] @abstractmethod
  • [ ] @static
  • [ ] @virtual
  • [ ] @override

docs.title: 4. What happens if a child class fails to implement an abstract method from its parent ABC?
docs.text:
• [ ] The code runs but the method does nothing
  • [ ] The child class executes the parent's empty method
  • [ ] Python throws an error when you try to instantiate the child class
  • [ ] Python automatically generates the method

docs.title: 5. What is the main purpose of Abstraction?
docs.text:
• [ ] To write more lines of code
  • [ ] To hide complex implementation details and expose only what is necessary
  • [ ] To make code run faster
  • [ ] To prevent other programmers from reading your code

  2. abc
  3. @abstractmethod

  5. To hide complex implementation details and expose only what is necessary

docs.title: 🧩 Composition vs Inheritance
docs.text: In OOP, we often need to choose how to relate two classes. - Inheritance: "Is-A" relationship. - Composition: "Has-A" relationship.

docs.title: 👨‍👦 Inheritance ("Is-A")
docs.text:
Use inheritance when the child class is a type of the parent class and shares its behavior. - Examples: Car is a Vehicle, Manager is an Employee.

Pros: - Code reuse (don't repeat common logic). - Polymorphism (treat child as parent).

Cons: - Tightly coupled (changes in parent affect all children). - Can lead to deep, confusing hierarchies.

docs.title: 🧱 Composition ("Has-A")
docs.text:
Use composition when the class has a component or part. Instead of inheriting, the class creates an instance of another class inside itself. - Examples: Car has an Engine, Computer has a CPU.

Pros: - Flexible (can change components at runtime). - Loosely coupled. - Avoids the "fragile base class" problem.

docs.title: 🧪 Example Comparison
docs.text:
Inheritance Approach: 

class Engine:
    def start(self): pass

class Car(Engine): # Weird: A Car IS NOT An Engine
    pass

Composition Approach: 

class Engine:
    def start(self): pass

class Car:
    def __init__(self):
        self.engine = Engine() # Correct: A Car HAS An Engine

    def start(self):
        self.engine.start() # Delegation

docs.title: ⚖️ The Rule of Thumb
docs.text:
"Favor object composition over class inheritance." — Design Patterns (GoF)

Unless there is a clear "Is-A" relationship, composition is usually safer and more flexible.

Next: SOLID Principles

docs.title: 1. What relationship does Inheritance represent?
docs.text:
• [ ] Has-A
  • [ ] Is-A
  • [ ] Uses-A
  • [ ] Was-A

docs.title: 2. What relationship does Composition represent?
docs.text:
• [ ] Has-A
  • [ ] Is-A
  • [ ] Kind-Of
  • [ ] Parent-Of

docs.title: 3. Which approach is generally generally preferred for flexibility and loose coupling?
docs.text:
• [ ] Deep Inheritance Hierarchies
  • [ ] Composition
  • [ ] Multiple Inheritance
  • [ ] Copy-Pasting Code

docs.title: 4. Why might you choose Composition over Inheritance?
docs.text:
• [ ] To change behavior at runtime by swapping components
  • [ ] To write less code initially
  • [ ] To enforce a strict hierarchy
  • [ ] Because inheritance is deprecated

docs.title: 5. In "A Car has an Engine", which is the correct design?
docs.text:
• [ ] class Car(Engine): ...
  • [ ] class Engine(Car): ...
  • [ ] class Car: def __init__(self): self.engine = Engine()
  • [ ] class Car: def engine(self): return "V8"

docs.title: Answers
docs.text:
1. Is-A
  2. Has-A
  3. Composition
  4. To change behavior at runtime by swapping components
  5. class Car: def __init__(self): self.engine = Engine()

docs.title: 🏗️ SOLID Principles
docs.text: SOLID is an acronym for five design principles intended to make software designs more understandable, flexible, and maintainable.

docs.title: 1. Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)
docs.text:
"A class should have only one reason to change."

Each class should focus on one single job. - Bad: User class handles database saving, email sending, AND logic. - Good: User class handles logic. UserRepository handles database. EmailService handles email.

docs.title: 2. Open/Closed Principle (OCP)
docs.text:
"Software entities should be open for extension, but closed for modification."

You should be able to add new functionality without changing existing code. - How: Use inheritance or interfaces (Polymorphism).

docs.title: 3. Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
docs.text:
"Objects of a superclass shall be replaceable with objects of its subclasses without breaking the application."

If Dog is a subclass of Animal, you should be able to plug Dog in anywhere Animal is used, and it should just work.

docs.title: 4. Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)
docs.text:
"Clients should not be forced to depend upon interfaces that they do not use."

Don't create massive "God Interfaces". Break them down into smaller, specific ones. - Bad: ISmartDevice with print, scan, fax. (A printer doesn't need to fax). - Good: IPrinter, IScanner, IFax.

docs.title: 5. Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)
docs.text:
"Depend upon abstractions, not concretions."

High-level modules (logic) should not depend on low-level modules (database/API). Both should depend on abstractions (interfaces). - How: Dependency Injection.

Return to Module Overview

docs.title: 🧩 Module 05: Functional Programming
docs.text:
Functional Programming (FP) is a paradigm that treats computation as the evaluation of pure functions and avoids shared state and mutable data. This module focuses on building predictable, testable code using FP ideas in Python.

Estimated Time: 8-10 hours Prerequisites: Module 01 (Foundations) Level: ⭐⭐ Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Pure Functions Deterministic functions without side effects determinism, referential transparency 02 Immutability Avoid changing data in place tuples, frozen data, copy-on-write 03 Higher-Order Functions Functions that take/return functions callbacks, composition 04 Lambda Expressions Anonymous functions for short logic lambda, inline functions 05 Map, Filter, Reduce Transform and reduce collections map, filter, reduce 06 Closures Functions that remember outer variables enclosing scope, nonlocal 07 Decorators Functions that wrap other functions @syntax, wrappers

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Write pure functions and reason about their behavior.
  • Use immutable data to avoid accidental bugs.
  • Compose logic with higher-order functions.
  • Use lambda expressions for concise transformations.
  • Leverage map/filter/reduce for collection processing.
  • Build and use closures for stateful functions.
  • Apply decorators to extend functionality cleanly.

docs.title: 🧼 Pure Functions
docs.text:
Pure functions are the foundation of functional programming. A pure function:

  1. Always returns the same output for the same inputs (deterministic).
  2. Has no side effects (doesn't modify external state, print, or mutate inputs).

docs.title: ✅ Why Pure Functions Matter
docs.text:
• Predictable: Easy to test and reason about.
  • Reusable: Safe to reuse across the codebase.
  • Composable: Works well with other functions.
  • Cacheable: Enables memoization because outputs only depend on inputs.

docs.title: ✅ Pure vs Impure
docs.text:
# Pure
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

# Impure (prints = side effect)
def add_and_log(a, b):
    result = a + b
    print(result)
    return result

docs.title: ✅ Referential Transparency
docs.text:
If a function is pure, you can replace the function call with its result without changing the program’s behavior.

def square(x):
    return x * x

square(3)  # always 9

docs.title: ✅ Avoiding Hidden State
docs.text:
counter = 0

def next_id():
    global counter
    counter += 1
    return counter

# Impure because it depends on external state

Better:

def next_id(current):
    return current + 1

docs.title: ✅ Guidelines for Pure Functions
docs.text:
• Don’t modify input arguments.
  • Don’t read global state.
  • Don’t write to files, databases, or the console.
  • Return a new value instead of mutating existing data.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Pure functions are deterministic and side-effect free.
  • They improve testability and maintainability.
  • They enable functional patterns like composition and memoization.

Next: Immutability

docs.title: 🧠 Pure Functions Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of pure functions!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which statement best describes a pure function?

  • A) It always prints its result
  • B) It mutates at least one argument
  • C) It always returns the same output for the same input and has no side effects
  • D) It must use recursion
Show Answer **C)** A pure function is deterministic and has no side effects.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why are pure functions easier to test?

  • A) They run faster
  • B) They don't need inputs
  • C) Their output depends only on their inputs
  • D) They always return integers
Show Answer **C)** You can test with fixed inputs and compare to expected outputs.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which is impure?

def f(x):
    return x * 2

def g(x):
    print(x)
    return x * 2
  • A) f
  • B) g
  • C) Both are pure
  • D) Neither is a function
Show Answer **B)** `g` has a side effect (printing).

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Referential transparency means:

  • A) You can replace a function call with its result without changing behavior
  • B) Functions must return references
  • C) You can only use global variables
  • D) Functions always mutate inputs
Show Answer **A)** Pure functions are referentially transparent.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which practice helps keep functions pure?

  • A) Mutate input lists in place
  • B) Read and write global variables
  • C) Return new values without changing inputs
  • D) Print inside every function
Show Answer **C)** Return new values, avoid mutation and side effects.

Back to Pure Functions README | Next: Immutability →

docs.title: 🧊 Immutability
docs.text: Immutability means data does not change after it's created. Instead of mutating existing values, you create new ones. This reduces bugs caused by shared state and makes code easier to reason about.

docs.title: ✅ Why Immutability?
docs.text:
• Predictable behavior — values don't change unexpectedly.
  • Safer concurrency — no race conditions on shared data.
  • Easier debugging — state changes are explicit.

docs.title: ✅ Immutable vs Mutable in Python
docs.text: Type Mutable? Examples int, float, str, tuple ❌ No numbers, strings, tuples list, dict, set ✅ Yes collections

docs.title: Strings (Immutable)
docs.text:
name = "alice"
upper = name.upper()  # creates a new string

docs.title: Tuples (Immutable)
docs.text:
point = (1, 2)
new_point = (point[0] + 1, point[1])

docs.title: Lists (Use Copies)
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3]
new_nums = nums + [4]   # new list

docs.title: ✅ Copy-on-Write
docs.text:
Instead of mutating an object, create a modified copy.

original = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}
updated = {**original, "age": 31}

docs.title: ✅ Immutability Tips
docs.text:
• Prefer tuple over list when you don’t need mutation.
  • Return new objects instead of mutating inputs.
  • Use dataclasses with frozen=True for immutable models.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Immutability reduces side effects.
  • You can emulate immutability with copies.
  • Immutable data works great with pure functions.

Next: Higher-Order Functions

docs.title: 🧠 Immutability Quiz
docs.text: Check your understanding of immutable data and copy-on-write patterns!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which Python type is immutable?

  • A) list
  • B) dict
  • C) tuple
  • D) set
Show Answer **C)** Tuples are immutable.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is a benefit of immutability?

  • A) Faster printing
  • B) Fewer unexpected side effects
  • C) More global variables
  • D) Automatic recursion
Show Answer **B)** Immutability reduces unexpected changes in shared state.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which creates a new list without mutating the original?

nums = [1, 2, 3]
  • A) nums.append(4)
  • B) nums[0] = 99
  • C) nums + [4]
  • D) nums.sort()
Show Answer **C)** `nums + [4]` returns a new list.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Why are immutable values safer with concurrency?

  • A) They can’t be changed by other threads
  • B) They always run faster
  • C) They avoid loops
  • D) They prevent exceptions
Show Answer **A)** If data can’t change, threads cannot corrupt it.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which expression creates a new dict with an updated key?

data = {"a": 1}
  • A) data["b"] = 2
  • B) {**data, "b": 2}
  • C) data.update({"b": 2})
  • D) del data["a"]
Show Answer **B)** `{**data, "b": 2}` creates a new dict.

Back to Immutability README | Next: Higher-Order Functions →

docs.title: 🔁 Higher-Order Functions
docs.text:
A higher-order function is a function that:

  1. Takes another function as an argument, and/or
  2. Returns a function as a result.

This is a core idea in functional programming that enables composition and reusable logic.

docs.title: ✅ Why It Matters
docs.text:
• Reusability: Write generic logic that works with many behaviors.
  • Composability: Build complex behavior from simple functions.
  • Clarity: Separate what you do from how you do it.

docs.title: ✅ Functions as Arguments
docs.text:
def apply_twice(func, value):
    return func(func(value))

def double(x):
    return x * 2

apply_twice(double, 3)  # 12

docs.title: ✅ Functions that Return Functions
docs.text:
def make_multiplier(factor):
    def multiply(x):
        return x * factor
    return multiply

times3 = make_multiplier(3)
times3(5)  # 15

docs.title: ✅ Composition
docs.text:
def compose(f, g):
    return lambda x: f(g(x))

def add1(x):
    return x + 1

def square(x):
    return x * x

add1_then_square = compose(square, add1)
add1_then_square(3)  # 16

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Functions can be treated like data.
  • Higher-order functions make code flexible and reusable.
  • They enable patterns like map/filter/reduce and decorators.

Next: Lambda Expressions

docs.title: 🧠 Higher-Order Functions Quiz
docs.text: Test your knowledge of higher-order functions!

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which best defines a higher-order function?

  • A) A function that only uses loops
  • B) A function that takes or returns another function
  • C) A function that always returns a list
  • D) A function with no parameters
Show Answer **B)** Higher-order functions take and/or return functions.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this return?

def apply_twice(f, x):
    return f(f(x))

def add1(x):
    return x + 1

apply_twice(add1, 3)
  • A) 3
  • B) 4
  • C) 5
  • D) 6
Show Answer **C)** add1(add1(3)) = 5.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which example shows a function returning a function?

  • A) 
    def f(x):
    return x * 2
  • B) 
    def make_adder(n):
    def add(x):
        return x + n
    return add
  • C) 
    def g(x):
    print(x)
  • D) 
    def h():
    return 42
Show Answer **B)** `make_adder` returns the inner `add` function.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Function composition compose(f, g) typically computes:

  • A) f + g
  • B) f(g(x))
  • C) g(f(x)) and f(g(x))
  • D) f(x) + g(x)
Show Answer **B)** Composition applies `g` first, then `f`.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Why are higher-order functions useful?

  • A) They replace all loops
  • B) They make functions run faster
  • C) They enable reusable, composable behavior
  • D) They avoid using variables
Show Answer **C)** They let you reuse and combine behavior cleanly.

Back to Higher-Order Functions README | Next: Lambda Expressions →

docs.title: ⚡ Lambda Expressions
docs.text: Lambda expressions are small, anonymous functions written in a single line. They are commonly used for short transformations and callbacks.

docs.title: ✅ Syntax
docs.text:
lambda args: expression

Examples:

square = lambda x: x * x
square(4)  # 16

add = lambda a, b: a + b
add(2, 3)  # 5

docs.title: ✅ When to Use
docs.text:
• Short, simple logic
  • Passed to higher-order functions (e.g., map, filter, sorted)
  • Inline callbacks

docs.title: Sorting with a key
docs.text:
names = ["Alice", "bob", "charlie"]
sorted(names, key=lambda n: n.lower())

docs.title: Filtering with a lambda
docs.text:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, nums))

docs.title: ⚠️ Keep It Readable
docs.text: If the logic gets complex, use a named function instead. Readability matters more than brevity.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Lambda functions are anonymous and single-expression.
  • Best for short, simple operations.
  • Often used with higher-order functions.

Next: Map, Filter, Reduce

docs.title: 🧠 Lambda Expressions Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of lambda expressions.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which is a valid lambda expression?

  • A) lambda x: x * 2
  • B) lambda (x): return x * 2
  • C) def lambda x: x * 2
  • D) lambda: x = 2
Show Answer **A)** `lambda x: x * 2` is valid.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this evaluate to?

(lambda a, b: a + b)(2, 3)
  • A) 2
  • B) 3
  • C) 5
  • D) Error
Show Answer **C)** It returns 5.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
When should you avoid lambdas?

  • A) When the logic is complex
  • B) When you need a short callback
  • C) When you need to pass a function
  • D) When you want fewer lines of code
Show Answer **A)** Use named functions for complex logic.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Which use of lambda is correct with sorted?

names = ["bob", "Alice", "charlie"]
  • A) sorted(names, key=lambda n: n.lower())
  • B) sorted(names, key=lambda(n) n.lower())
  • C) sorted(names, key=lambda: n.lower())
  • D) sorted(names, lambda n: n.lower())
Show Answer **A)** The key function must accept one argument.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which statement is true about lambda expressions?

  • A) They can contain multiple statements
  • B) They are always faster than def
  • C) They are anonymous, single-expression functions
  • D) They can only be used with map/filter
Show Answer **C)** Lambdas are anonymous single-expression functions.

Back to Lambda README | Next: Map, Filter, Reduce →

docs.title: 🧮 Map, Filter, Reduce
docs.text:
These three functions are classic tools in functional programming:

  • map: transform each element
  • filter: keep elements that match a condition
  • reduce: combine all elements into one value

docs.title: ✅ map
docs.text:
Apply a function to every element.

nums = [1, 2, 3]
squares = list(map(lambda x: x * x, nums))
# [1, 4, 9]

docs.title: ✅ filter
docs.text:
Keep items that satisfy a predicate.

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, nums))
# [2, 4]

docs.title: ✅ reduce
docs.text:
Reduce combines values into a single result. In Python, it lives in functools.

from functools import reduce
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
total = reduce(lambda acc, x: acc + x, nums, 0)
# 10

docs.title: ✅ Alternatives
docs.text:
Python also offers comprehensions, which are often clearer:

sq = [x * x for x in nums]
ev = [x for x in nums if x % 2 == 0]

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• map transforms, filter selects, reduce aggregates.
  • Use lambdas for short logic, named functions for clarity.
  • Comprehensions are often more readable in Python.

Next: Closures

docs.title: 🧠 Map, Filter, Reduce Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of map, filter, and reduce.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does map do?

  • A) Filters elements by condition
  • B) Transforms each element using a function
  • C) Combines elements into one
  • D) Sorts a list
Show Answer **B)** `map` applies a function to each element.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this produce?

list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, [1, 2, 3, 4]))
  • A) [1, 3]
  • B) [2, 4]
  • C) [1, 2, 3, 4]
  • D) []
Show Answer **B)** It keeps the even numbers.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Where is reduce imported from?

  • A) math
  • B) itertools
  • C) functools
  • D) collections
Show Answer **C)** `reduce` is in `functools`.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What does this return?

from functools import reduce
reduce(lambda acc, x: acc + x, [1, 2, 3], 0)
  • A) 3
  • B) 6
  • C) 0
  • D) Error
Show Answer **B)** It sums to 6.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which Python alternative is often more readable than map/filter?

  • A) List comprehensions
  • B) while loops only
  • C) try/except
  • D) slicing
Show Answer **A)** List comprehensions are often clearer in Python.

Back to Map/Filter/Reduce README | Next: Closures →

docs.title: 🪟 Closures
docs.text: A closure is a function that remembers the variables from its outer (enclosing) scope, even after that outer function has finished executing.

docs.title: ✅ Why Closures Matter
docs.text:
• Let you create customized functions (function factories)
  • Hide internal state without classes
  • Enable patterns like decorators

docs.title: ✅ Example: Function Factory
docs.text:
def make_adder(n):
    def add(x):
        return x + n
    return add

add5 = make_adder(5)
add5(10)  # 15

Here, add remembers the value of n even after make_adder returns.

docs.title: ✅ Using nonlocal
docs.text:
To update an outer variable, use nonlocal.

def counter():
    count = 0
    def inc():
        nonlocal count
        count += 1
        return count
    return inc

next_count = counter()
next_count()  # 1
next_count()  # 2

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Closures capture values from enclosing scopes.
  • They are useful for customization and encapsulation.
  • nonlocal lets you update captured variables.

Next: Decorators

docs.title: 🧠 Closures Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of closures.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is a closure?

  • A) A function with no parameters
  • B) A function that remembers variables from its enclosing scope
  • C) A function that always returns None
  • D) A function that only uses global variables
Show Answer **B)** Closures capture variables from their enclosing scope.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does this return?

def make_adder(n):
    def add(x):
        return x + n
    return add

add3 = make_adder(3)
add3(4)
  • A) 3
  • B) 4
  • C) 7
  • D) Error
Show Answer **C)** 4 + 3 = 7.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Why use nonlocal?

  • A) To import a module
  • B) To create a new local variable
  • C) To modify a variable from an enclosing scope
  • D) To access global variables
Show Answer **C)** `nonlocal` lets you update the outer variable.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Closures are useful because they:

  • A) Replace classes entirely
  • B) Allow functions to keep internal state
  • C) Always run faster
  • D) Prevent all bugs
Show Answer **B)** Closures can store state without classes.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which pattern uses closures often?

  • A) Decorators
  • B) List slicing
  • C) File I/O
  • D) Exception handling
Show Answer **A)** Decorators commonly use closures.

Back to Closures README | Next: Decorators →

docs.title: 🎁 Decorators
docs.text: Decorators are functions that wrap other functions to extend or modify their behavior. They are built on higher-order functions and closures.

docs.title: ✅ Basic Idea
docs.text:
def logger(func):
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Calling {func.__name__}")
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

@logger
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

Calling greet("Alice") now prints a log and returns the greeting.

docs.title: ✅ Why Decorators?
docs.text:
• Add logging or timing
  • Validate inputs
  • Cache results
  • Enforce permissions

docs.title: ✅ Using functools.wraps
docs.text:
To preserve the original function’s metadata (like __name__ and docstring):

from functools import wraps

def logger(func):
    @wraps(func)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Calling {func.__name__}")
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Decorators wrap functions to add behavior.
  • They use higher-order functions and closures.
  • @decorator is syntax sugar for func = decorator(func).

Back to Closures

docs.title: 🧠 Decorators Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of decorators.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does @decorator syntax do?

  • A) Calls the function immediately
  • B) Replaces the function with decorator(function)
  • C) Creates a class
  • D) Imports a module
Show Answer **B)** `@decorator` is syntax sugar for `func = decorator(func)`.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why use functools.wraps inside decorators?

  • A) To speed up functions
  • B) To preserve the wrapped function's metadata
  • C) To create recursion
  • D) To avoid arguments
Show Answer **B)** `wraps` preserves `__name__`, docstring, etc.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which decorator adds behavior without changing the original function body?

  • A) A closure
  • B) A class method
  • C) A wrapper function
  • D) A global variable
Show Answer **C)** Decorators wrap functions with a wrapper.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What is a decorator factory?

  • A) A function that returns a decorator
  • B) A decorator that returns a class
  • C) A function that returns None
  • D) A module for testing
Show Answer **A)** A decorator factory lets you pass arguments to decorators.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which use case fits decorators best?

  • A) Sorting lists
  • B) Logging and timing function calls
  • C) Reading files
  • D) Creating tuples
Show Answer **B)** Decorators are commonly used for logging, timing, caching, etc.

Back to Decorators README

docs.title: 🧠 Module 06: Software Design
docs.text:
Software design is about writing code that stays readable, changeable, and reliable as it grows. This module focuses on practical design principles you can apply daily — even in small scripts — to reduce bugs and make future changes easier.

Estimated Time: 6-8 hours Prerequisites: Module 01 (Foundations), Module 04 (OOP Concepts), Module 05 (Functional Programming) Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Upper-Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 DRY Principle Remove duplication and centralize knowledge duplication, single source of truth 02 KISS Principle Prefer simple solutions that are easy to understand simplicity, readability 03 YAGNI Principle Build what you need now, not what you might need later scope, overengineering 04 Separation of Concerns Split responsibilities so each part has one job layers, boundaries, modules 05 Coupling and Cohesion Design for low coupling and high cohesion dependencies, responsibility 06 Code Smells Recognize warning signs of maintainability issues long functions, god objects 07 Refactoring Improve code structure without changing behavior safe changes, small steps

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Spot duplication and apply DRY without over-abstracting.
  • Choose simpler designs and explain why they’re safer.
  • Avoid speculative features and premature abstractions (YAGNI).
  • Organize code by responsibility using separation of concerns.
  • Reduce coupling, increase cohesion, and understand trade-offs.
  • Identify common code smells and propose concrete improvements.
  • Refactor confidently using small, behavior-preserving steps.

docs.title: 🧩 DRY Principle (Don't Repeat Yourself)
docs.text: DRY means: every piece of knowledge should have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation in the system. In practice, it’s about reducing duplication so that when requirements change, you change code in one place, not five.

docs.title: ✅ What Counts as Duplication?
docs.text:
Duplication isn’t only copy/paste.

  • Copy/paste code (same logic repeated)
  • Parallel logic (same idea expressed differently in multiple places)
  • Duplicated rules (e.g., validation constraints repeated in UI + API + DB)

docs.title: ✅ Why DRY Matters
docs.text:
• Fewer bugs: Fix once, benefit everywhere.
  • Faster changes: Requirements change constantly.
  • Clearer intent: Shared logic becomes a named concept.

docs.title: ⚠️ DRY vs “Over-Abstraction”
docs.text:
DRY is not the same as “make everything generic”.

  • Good DRY: Extract shared logic with a clear name.
  • Bad DRY: Create complex helper layers that hide simple behavior.

A useful rule: if two pieces of code are identical by accident and likely to diverge soon, it may be okay to keep them separate.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Refactor Duplication
docs.text:
Before (duplicated discounts):

def vip_price(price):
    return price * 0.8

def student_price(price):
    return price * 0.8

After (single source of truth):

def apply_discount(price, percent):
    return price * (1 - percent / 100)

vip_price = lambda p: apply_discount(p, 20)
student_price = lambda p: apply_discount(p, 20)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• DRY reduces repeated knowledge, not just repeated lines.
  • Centralize rules that must stay consistent.
  • Don’t over-abstract; keep the simplest shared design that works.

Next: KISS Principle

docs.title: 🧠 DRY Principle Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself).

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the main goal of the DRY principle?

  • A) Make code shorter at all costs
  • B) Ensure each piece of knowledge exists in one place
  • C) Avoid using functions
  • D) Use more classes
Show Answer **B)** DRY is about a single source of truth for rules/knowledge.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is an example of duplication (DRY violation)?

  • A) Using a helper function in two places
  • B) Copy/pasting the same validation logic in multiple functions
  • C) Writing tests
  • D) Renaming variables for clarity
Show Answer **B)** Duplicated rules or logic means multiple places to update.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
When can duplication be acceptable?

  • A) Always; DRY is optional
  • B) Never; duplication is always wrong
  • C) When code is likely to diverge soon and abstraction would be misleading
  • D) Only in Python
Show Answer **C)** Sometimes two similar things are not truly the same concept.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What is a common risk of applying DRY too aggressively?

  • A) Too many tests
  • B) Over-abstraction and hard-to-understand generic code
  • C) Functions becoming shorter
  • D) Fewer bugs
Show Answer **B)** DRY done poorly can create complex indirection.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which change best supports DRY?

  • A) Replace duplicated blocks with a well-named helper
  • B) Duplicate code so it's easier to read
  • C) Put everything in one huge function
  • D) Add more global variables
Show Answer **A)** Extracting shared logic creates a single source of truth.

Back to DRY README | Next: KISS →

docs.title: 🪶 KISS Principle (Keep It Simple, Stupid)
docs.text: KISS means: prefer the simplest solution that correctly solves the problem. Simple code is easier to read, test, debug, and change.

docs.title: ✅ What “Simple” Means
docs.text:
Simplicity is mostly about reducing cognitive load:

  • Fewer moving parts
  • Clear data flow
  • Obvious naming
  • Minimal “magic”

docs.title: ✅ Why KISS Matters
docs.text:
• Lower bug risk: Complex designs have more failure modes.
  • Easier onboarding: New readers can follow the code faster.
  • Faster iteration: Simple code is easier to refactor safely.

docs.title: ⚠️ Simple vs Easy
docs.text:
• “Easy now” might be hacks that create future pain.
  • “Simple” is code that stays understandable over time.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Prefer a Straight Line
docs.text:
Instead of nesting and special-casing:

if user is not None:
    if user.is_active:
        if user.has_permission("edit"):
            return True
return False

Prefer a clear expression:

def can_edit(user):
    return bool(user and user.is_active and user.has_permission("edit"))

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Choose designs that are easy to explain.
  • Reduce branching, indirection, and clever tricks.
  • Optimize for readability first; performance comes later (when proven needed).

Back: DRY Principle | Next: YAGNI Principle

docs.title: 🧠 KISS Principle Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of KISS (Keep It Simple).

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does KISS encourage?

  • A) Using as many abstractions as possible
  • B) Choosing the simplest correct solution
  • C) Avoiding functions
  • D) Always optimizing for performance first
Show Answer **B)** KISS favors simpler designs that are easier to understand.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is most likely to violate KISS?

  • A) A direct loop with clear variable names
  • B) A small helper function with a descriptive name
  • C) A deep class hierarchy for a one-file script
  • D) Early returns that reduce nesting
Show Answer **C)** Extra layers add complexity without solving real needs.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What is a benefit of simpler code?

  • A) It always runs faster
  • B) It is easier to test, debug, and change
  • C) It avoids needing inputs
  • D) It removes the need for documentation
Show Answer **B)** Fewer moving parts means fewer failure modes.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Why are early returns often considered more “KISS” than deep nesting?

  • A) They are always shorter
  • B) They reduce indentation and make logic easier to follow
  • C) They force recursion
  • D) They remove the need for conditions
Show Answer **B)** Less nesting makes the happy-path clearer.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which trade-off is most aligned with KISS?

  • A) Add a framework now “just in case”
  • B) Use clever one-liners to show skill
  • C) Prefer readable code even if it uses a few extra lines
  • D) Avoid naming things
Show Answer **C)** Readability beats cleverness for maintainability.

Back to KISS README | Next: YAGNI →

docs.title: 🚫 YAGNI Principle (You Aren't Gonna Need It)
docs.text: YAGNI means: don’t build features, abstractions, or flexibility until you actually need them. It’s a guardrail against speculative design.

docs.title: ✅ What YAGNI Prevents
docs.text:
Common “future-proofing” traps:

  • Building a plugin system for a script with one use case
  • Adding configuration options nobody asked for
  • Writing generalized frameworks instead of finishing the task

docs.title: ✅ Why YAGNI Matters
docs.text:
• Less code: Fewer bugs and less maintenance.
  • Faster delivery: Ship working value sooner.
  • Better designs: Real requirements create better abstractions than guesses.

docs.title: ⚠️ YAGNI Doesn’t Mean “No Planning”
docs.text:
You can still design with:

  • Clear boundaries
  • Good naming
  • Modest, reversible choices

YAGNI only says: don’t pay the cost of complexity before the value exists.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Avoid Premature Generalization
docs.text:
Before (generalized too soon):

class StorageBackend:
    def save(self, key, value):
        raise NotImplementedError

If you only need a dictionary today, start simple:

def save(store, key, value):
    store[key] = value

When requirements change (e.g., DB storage), then introduce an interface.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Build for current requirements, not imagined ones.
  • Prefer small, reversible steps.
  • Let abstractions emerge from real repetition and constraints.

Back: KISS Principle | Next: Separation of Concerns

docs.title: 🧠 YAGNI Principle Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It).

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does YAGNI warn against?

  • A) Writing tests
  • B) Building speculative features “just in case”
  • C) Using functions
  • D) Refactoring
Show Answer **B)** YAGNI is a guardrail against overengineering.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is most aligned with YAGNI?

  • A) Add a plugin system before any plugins exist
  • B) Write the simplest solution that meets today’s requirements
  • C) Create multiple layers of abstraction for future flexibility
  • D) Optimize performance before measuring
Show Answer **B)** Let real needs drive new abstractions.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Why can “future-proofing” be harmful?

  • A) It always makes code faster
  • B) It adds complexity and maintenance cost immediately
  • C) It removes the need for documentation
  • D) It guarantees requirements won’t change
Show Answer **B)** You pay the cost now, even if the value never arrives.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Does YAGNI mean “no planning”?

  • A) Yes, never think ahead
  • B) No, it means avoid paying for complexity too early
  • C) Yes, write everything as a one-liner
  • D) No, it means always build a framework
Show Answer **B)** You can design clean boundaries without overbuilding features.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
When is it reasonable to introduce an abstraction?

  • A) When you have real repetition or multiple concrete implementations
  • B) Before writing any code
  • C) Only when using OOP
  • D) Only for performance
Show Answer **A)** Real repetition and constraints are good signals.

Back to YAGNI README | Next: Separation of Concerns →

docs.title: 🧱 Separation of Concerns
docs.text: Separation of concerns (SoC) means organizing code so that each part focuses on a distinct responsibility. When responsibilities are mixed, changes become risky because unrelated behavior is tangled together.

docs.title: ✅ Common “Concerns” in Programs
docs.text:
• Input/Output: CLI, HTTP, file reading/writing
  • Business logic: rules and computations
  • Data access: databases, APIs
  • Presentation: formatting, UI, reporting

docs.title: ✅ Why SoC Matters
docs.text:
• Easier changes: UI changes don’t break business rules.
  • Better tests: business logic can be tested without I/O.
  • Cleaner boundaries: reduces coupling between parts.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Split I/O From Logic
docs.text:
Instead of mixing parsing + computation + printing:

def run():
    text = input("Enter numbers: ")
    nums = [int(x) for x in text.split(",")]
    print(sum(nums) / len(nums))

Separate concerns:

def parse_numbers(text):
    return [int(x) for x in text.split(",")]

def average(nums):
    return sum(nums) / len(nums)

def run():
    nums = parse_numbers(input("Enter numbers: "))
    print(average(nums))

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Keep I/O at the edges; keep logic pure where possible.
  • Group related responsibilities together.
  • Boundaries make testing and refactoring safer.

Back: YAGNI Principle | Next: Coupling and Cohesion

docs.title: 🧠 Separation of Concerns Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of separation of concerns.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is separation of concerns (SoC)?

  • A) Putting all code in one file
  • B) Splitting a program into parts that each handle a distinct responsibility
  • C) Avoiding functions
  • D) Using only classes
Show Answer **B)** SoC organizes code by responsibility.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why does SoC often improve testability?

  • A) It removes the need for inputs
  • B) It lets you test business logic without I/O
  • C) It makes code longer
  • D) It forces recursion
Show Answer **B)** Pure logic is easier to test than code that reads/writes externally.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which concern is best kept at the edges of the program?

  • A) Core calculations
  • B) Business rules
  • C) Reading user input / writing to files
  • D) Data transformations
Show Answer **C)** I/O is typically an edge concern.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What’s a common symptom of mixed concerns?

  • A) Small functions
  • B) Clear module boundaries
  • C) A function that parses, computes, and prints all at once
  • D) Low coupling
Show Answer **C)** Mixed responsibilities make change risky.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which refactor best supports SoC?

  • A) Combine parsing and printing into one function
  • B) Extract business logic into pure functions
  • C) Add more global variables
  • D) Remove unit tests
Show Answer **B)** Isolating logic from I/O makes code easier to change and test.

Back to SoC README | Next: Coupling and Cohesion →

docs.title: 🔗 Coupling and Cohesion
docs.text:
Two big design qualities:

  • Coupling: how strongly one part depends on another.
  • Cohesion: how well the responsibilities inside a part belong together.

Great designs aim for low coupling and high cohesion.

docs.title: ✅ Low Coupling
docs.text:
Low coupling means components can change independently.

Signs of high coupling:

  • Many imports and cross-calls between modules
  • One small change forces changes in many places
  • Code can’t be reused without dragging dependencies along

docs.title: ✅ High Cohesion
docs.text:
High cohesion means a module/class/function does one focused job.

Signs of low cohesion:

  • “Utility” modules that contain unrelated helpers
  • Classes with many unrelated methods
  • Functions that do validation + parsing + storage + formatting

docs.title: ✅ Example: Improve Cohesion
docs.text:
Before (mixed responsibilities):

def process_order(order):
    validate(order)
    save_to_db(order)
    send_email(order)
    print("Done")

After (clear responsibilities):

def validate_order(order):
    ...

def persist_order(order):
    ...

def notify_order_created(order):
    ...

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Low coupling reduces “blast radius” of change.
  • High cohesion makes code easier to locate and reason about.
  • SoC often improves both coupling and cohesion.

Back: Separation of Concerns | Next: Code Smells

docs.title: 🧠 Coupling and Cohesion Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of coupling and cohesion.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is coupling?

  • A) How fast code runs
  • B) How strongly one part depends on another
  • C) How many lines a file has
  • D) How many tests exist
Show Answer **B)** Coupling measures dependency strength.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is cohesion?

  • A) How focused the responsibilities inside a module/class/function are
  • B) How many imports exist
  • C) How many bugs exist
  • D) How many features exist
Show Answer **A)** High cohesion means a focused responsibility.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which combination is usually best?

  • A) High coupling, low cohesion
  • B) Low coupling, high cohesion
  • C) High coupling, high cohesion
  • D) Low coupling, low cohesion
Show Answer **B)** That makes change safer and code easier to understand.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What is a common sign of high coupling?

  • A) You can change one module without touching others
  • B) A small change forces edits across many files
  • C) Functions have clear names
  • D) Tests are fast
Show Answer **B)** High coupling increases the blast radius of change.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
How can you reduce coupling?

  • A) Hard-code dependencies everywhere
  • B) Use dependency injection (pass dependencies as parameters)
  • C) Put everything in global variables
  • D) Avoid naming things
Show Answer **B)** Passing dependencies makes components easier to replace and test.

Back to Coupling & Cohesion README | Next: Code Smells →

docs.title: 🕵️ Code Smells
docs.text: A code smell is a warning sign that code might be hard to maintain. Smells aren’t necessarily bugs — they’re clues that design could be improved.

docs.title: ✅ Common Code Smells
docs.text:
• Duplicated code (DRY violation)
  • Long function (does too much)
  • God object (one class knows/does everything)
  • Too many parameters (hard to understand and call)
  • Feature envy (one object uses another’s data too much)
  • Primitive obsession (strings/ints used where a type would help)
  • Shotgun surgery (small change requires many edits)

docs.title: ✅ Why Smells Matter
docs.text:
• They predict future pain: bugs, slow changes, fragile tests.
  • They guide refactoring: you don’t refactor randomly — you refactor to remove specific smells.

docs.title: ✅ Smells Are Contextual
docs.text:
A smell might be fine when:

  • The code is tiny and disposable.
  • Performance constraints require a trade-off.
  • You’re in the middle of a transition (temporary duplication).

The key is being intentional.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Smells are symptoms, not diagnoses.
  • Use smells to start design conversations.
  • Many smells can be reduced through small, safe refactors.

Back: Coupling and Cohesion | Next: Refactoring

docs.title: 🧠 Code Smells Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of code smells.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
A code smell is:

  • A) A syntax error
  • B) A warning sign that code may be hard to maintain
  • C) A performance benchmark
  • D) A unit test
Show Answer **B)** Smells suggest design issues but aren’t necessarily bugs.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is a common code smell?

  • A) Clear naming
  • B) Long functions
  • C) Small focused modules
  • D) Good tests
Show Answer **B)** Long functions often hide mixed responsibilities.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What is “shotgun surgery”?

  • A) Changing one line in one file
  • B) Needing many small edits across many files for a single change
  • C) Running tests frequently
  • D) Removing duplication
Show Answer **B)** It’s a sign of high coupling and scattered knowledge.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Are code smells always wrong?

  • A) Yes, always
  • B) No, they depend on context and trade-offs
  • C) Yes, but only in Python
  • D) No, because they are always bugs
Show Answer **B)** Sometimes a smell is acceptable temporarily or for constraints.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
A good response to code smells is usually:

  • A) Ignore them
  • B) Refactor in small steps with a safety net
  • C) Rewrite everything from scratch
  • D) Add more global state
Show Answer **B)** Refactoring improves structure while keeping behavior.

Back to Code Smells README | Next: Refactoring →

docs.title: 🛠️ Refactoring
docs.text: Refactoring is improving the internal structure of code without changing what it does. The goal is to make code easier to understand and safer to modify.

docs.title: ✅ When to Refactor
docs.text:
• When you spot repeated code (DRY)
  • When a function/class is doing too much (low cohesion)
  • When adding a feature feels risky (high coupling)
  • After fixing a bug (so it doesn’t come back)

docs.title: ✅ Refactoring Safety
docs.text:
Refactoring is safest when you have a safety net:

  • Good automated tests
  • Small, incremental changes
  • Frequent re-running of examples/tests

docs.title: ✅ Common Refactoring Moves
docs.text:
• Extract function / extract class
  • Rename for clarity
  • Replace conditionals with polymorphism (when appropriate)
  • Introduce value objects instead of primitive obsession
  • Reduce parameter lists by grouping data

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Refactor in small steps and keep behavior the same.
  • Use design principles to guide what to refactor.
  • Prefer clarity over cleverness.

Back: Code Smells

docs.title: 🧠 Refactoring Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of refactoring.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Refactoring is best defined as:

  • A) Changing behavior to add new features
  • B) Improving internal structure without changing behavior
  • C) Deleting code until it works
  • D) Optimizing only for speed
Show Answer **B)** Refactoring keeps behavior the same.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What makes refactoring safer?

  • A) Large changes all at once
  • B) A good test suite and small steps
  • C) Avoiding running the code
  • D) Renaming everything randomly
Show Answer **B)** Tests + small steps catch mistakes early.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which is a common refactoring move?

  • A) Extract function
  • B) Add global variables
  • C) Copy/paste logic
  • D) Remove validation
Show Answer **A)** Extracting clarifies intent and reduces duplication.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What’s the relationship between code smells and refactoring?

  • A) Smells are bugs that must be fixed immediately
  • B) Smells can signal where refactoring might help
  • C) Refactoring creates smells
  • D) They are unrelated
Show Answer **B)** Smells guide you to structural improvements.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What’s a good refactoring habit?

  • A) Make a change, re-run tests/examples
  • B) Avoid renaming variables
  • C) Never extract helpers
  • D) Refactor without understanding behavior
Show Answer **A)** Small steps + frequent verification is the safest workflow.

Back to Refactoring README

docs.title: 🎨 Module 07: Design Patterns
docs.text:
Design patterns are reusable solutions to common software design problems. They help you communicate ideas clearly, avoid reinventing the wheel, and build systems that are easier to change and extend.

Estimated Time: 10-12 hours Prerequisites: Module 04 (OOP Concepts), Module 06 (Software Design) Level: ⭐⭐⭐⭐ Advanced

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Creational Patterns How objects are created and configured singleton, factory, builder 02 Structural Patterns How parts are composed into larger structures adapter, decorator, facade 03 Behavioral Patterns How objects communicate and share responsibilities observer, strategy, command

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Explain when and why to use design patterns.
  • Choose a suitable pattern for a given design problem.
  • Identify common patterns in real-world code.
  • Implement basic versions of creational, structural, and behavioral patterns.

docs.title: 🏗️ Creational Design Patterns
docs.text: Creational patterns focus on how objects are created. They help you control construction so that code stays flexible, testable, and easy to extend.

docs.title: ✅ Why Creational Patterns Matter
docs.text:
• Encapsulate creation logic so the rest of your code stays simple.
  • Reduce coupling to specific classes or constructors.
  • Improve testability by swapping implementations easily.

docs.title: 1) Singleton
docs.text:
Ensures a class has only one instance and provides a global access point.

✅ Use when: you need a single shared resource (config, logger). ⚠️ Watch out: too much global state can hurt testability.

docs.title: 2) Factory (Simple/Factory Method)
docs.text:
Delegates object creation to a function or method based on input.

✅ Use when: you want to create related objects without hard-coding classes.

docs.title: 3) Builder
docs.text:
Creates complex objects step-by-step, often with a fluent API.

✅ Use when: objects have many optional parts or configurations.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Simple Factory
docs.text:
class EmailNotification:
    def send(self, msg):
        print(f"Email: {msg}")


class SMSNotification:
    def send(self, msg):
        print(f"SMS: {msg}")


def notification_factory(kind):
    if kind == "email":
        return EmailNotification()
    if kind == "sms":
        return SMSNotification()
    raise ValueError("Unknown notification type")


notifier = notification_factory("email")
notifier.send("Hello!")

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Creational patterns manage object creation complexity.
  • Factories centralize construction decisions.
  • Builders help when many optional fields are needed.

Next: Structural Patterns →

docs.title: 🧠 Creational Patterns Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of Singleton, Factory, and Builder.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the main goal of creational patterns?

  • A) Optimize database queries
  • B) Control how objects are created
  • C) Prevent inheritance
  • D) Make classes larger
Show Answer **B)** Creational patterns manage and simplify object creation.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which pattern provides a single shared instance?

  • A) Adapter
  • B) Singleton
  • C) Observer
  • D) Strategy
Show Answer **B)** Singleton enforces a single instance.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which pattern helps create different objects based on input?

  • A) Factory
  • B) Decorator
  • C) Command
  • D) Proxy
Show Answer **A)** Factories choose which class to instantiate.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
When is a Builder most useful?

  • A) When objects are extremely small
  • B) When objects have many optional parts
  • C) When you want global state
  • D) When you want to hide methods
Show Answer **B)** Builders handle complex, step-by-step construction.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What is a common risk of Singleton misuse?

  • A) Too many classes
  • B) Hidden global state and hard testing
  • C) Slower loops
  • D) Excessive comments
Show Answer **B)** Singletons can behave like global variables.

Back to Creational README | Next: Structural →

docs.title: 🧱 Structural Design Patterns
docs.text: Structural patterns focus on how objects and classes are composed to form larger structures. They help you build systems that are flexible, maintainable, and easy to extend without changing existing code.

docs.title: ✅ Why Structural Patterns Matter
docs.text:
• Improve flexibility by wrapping or adapting existing components.
  • Reduce coupling between parts of the system.
  • Add features without modifying existing classes.

docs.title: 1) Adapter
docs.text:
Makes one interface compatible with another.

✅ Use when: you need to integrate a legacy or third‑party class.

docs.title: 2) Decorator
docs.text:
Adds behavior to objects dynamically by wrapping them.

✅ Use when: you want optional features without subclass explosion.

docs.title: 3) Facade
docs.text:
Provides a simple interface to a complex system.

✅ Use when: clients should only see a small, easy entry point.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Adapter
docs.text:
class LegacyPayment:
    def pay_cents(self, cents):
        print(f"Paid {cents} cents")


class PaymentAdapter:
    def __init__(self, legacy_payment):
        self.legacy_payment = legacy_payment

    def pay(self, dollars):
        self.legacy_payment.pay_cents(int(dollars * 100))


gateway = PaymentAdapter(LegacyPayment())
gateway.pay(9.99)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Structural patterns organize how parts fit together.
  • Adapters translate interfaces, decorators extend behavior.
  • Facades simplify complex subsystems.

Next: Behavioral Patterns →

docs.title: 🧠 Structural Patterns Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of Adapter, Decorator, and Facade.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the main purpose of an Adapter?

  • A) Add caching
  • B) Translate one interface into another
  • C) Ensure a single instance
  • D) Schedule background jobs
Show Answer **B)** Adapters make incompatible interfaces work together.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which pattern adds behavior by wrapping an object?

  • A) Decorator
  • B) Factory
  • C) Singleton
  • D) Strategy
Show Answer **A)** Decorators wrap objects to extend behavior.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
When is a Facade useful?

  • A) When you want to replace a database
  • B) When you want to hide a complex subsystem
  • C) When you want to build objects step-by-step
  • D) When you want a global variable
Show Answer **B)** Facades provide a simple interface to complex systems.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Adapters are most helpful when:

  • A) All classes are already compatible
  • B) You need to integrate legacy or third‑party code
  • C) You want to remove classes
  • D) You want to reduce loops
Show Answer **B)** Adapters bridge mismatched interfaces.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which statement about decorators is true?

  • A) They require subclassing every time
  • B) They add behavior without changing original classes
  • C) They remove methods from objects
  • D) They only work with functions
Show Answer **B)** Decorators wrap to extend behavior without modification.

Back to Structural README | Next: Behavioral →

docs.title: 🧠 Behavioral Design Patterns
docs.text: Behavioral patterns focus on how objects communicate and share responsibilities. They help you design interactions that are flexible, testable, and easy to change.

docs.title: ✅ Why Behavioral Patterns Matter
docs.text:
• Reduce tight coupling between objects that need to collaborate.
  • Encapsulate behavior so it can change independently.
  • Make systems extensible by plugging in new behaviors.

docs.title: 1) Observer
docs.text:
One object (subject) notifies multiple observers when its state changes.

✅ Use when: you need event-style updates (UI updates, notifications).

docs.title: 2) Strategy
docs.text:
Encapsulates interchangeable algorithms behind a common interface.

✅ Use when: you want to swap logic without changing the caller.

docs.title: 3) Command
docs.text:
Encapsulates an action as an object, enabling queues, history, or undo.

✅ Use when: you need to log, delay, or undo operations.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Strategy
docs.text:
class StandardShipping:
    def cost(self, total):
        return 5 if total < 50 else 0


class ExpressShipping:
    def cost(self, total):
        return 15


def checkout(total, shipping_strategy):
    return total + shipping_strategy.cost(total)


total = checkout(40, ExpressShipping())

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Behavioral patterns structure collaboration between objects.
  • Observers react to events without direct coupling.
  • Strategies and commands make behavior swappable and reusable.

Back: Structural Patterns

docs.title: 🧠 Behavioral Patterns Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of Observer, Strategy, and Command.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does the Observer pattern enable?

  • A) One object notified by many subjects
  • B) Many observers notified when a subject changes
  • C) Global access to a single instance
  • D) Automatic caching
Show Answer **B)** Observers subscribe to updates from a subject.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which pattern encapsulates interchangeable algorithms?

  • A) Strategy
  • B) Adapter
  • C) Facade
  • D) Builder
Show Answer **A)** Strategy lets you swap algorithms without changing callers.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What is a common use for the Command pattern?

  • A) Building objects step-by-step
  • B) Wrapping incompatible interfaces
  • C) Queuing, logging, or undoing actions
  • D) Enforcing a single instance
Show Answer **C)** Commands encapsulate actions for history or delayed execution.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Which statement is true about behavioral patterns?

  • A) They only apply to databases
  • B) They focus on object collaboration
  • C) They replace functions
  • D) They remove the need for classes
Show Answer **B)** Behavioral patterns model interactions between objects.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
When should you use Strategy instead of if/else logic?

  • A) When the algorithm never changes
  • B) When you want to swap behaviors at runtime
  • C) When you want a single instance
  • D) When you want global state
Show Answer **B)** Strategy makes behavior swappable without changing callers.

Back to Behavioral README

docs.title: 🚧 Module 08: Error Handling
docs.text:
Error handling is the skill of writing programs that fail safely, communicate clearly, and recover when possible. This module teaches how to use exceptions, write defensive checks, create custom errors, and log failures for real-world debugging.

Estimated Time: 6-8 hours Prerequisites: Module 01 (Foundations) Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Upper-Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Exceptions What exceptions are and why they exist raise, built-in errors, stack trace 02 Try/Except/Finally Catching, handling, and cleaning up try, except, else, finally 03 Custom Exceptions Defining your own error types subclasses, hierarchy, messages 04 Defensive Programming Preventing errors before they happen validation, guards, assertions 05 Logging Recording errors and context logging levels, handlers, tracebacks

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Explain what exceptions are and how they propagate.
  • Use try/except/else/finally to handle failures safely.
  • Create custom exceptions to make errors meaningful.
  • Apply defensive checks to avoid fragile code paths.
  • Log errors with enough context to debug real issues.
