docs.title: ⚠️ Exceptions
docs.text: Exceptions are runtime signals that something went wrong. Instead of silently failing, Python raises an exception and unwinds the call stack until it’s handled.

docs.title: ✅ What Is an Exception?
docs.text:
• A type that represents an error (e.g., ValueError, KeyError).
  • A message that describes the problem.
  • A stack trace showing where the error happened.

Exceptions can be raised by Python or by your own code.

docs.title: ✅ Why Exceptions Matter
docs.text:
• They stop incorrect execution early.
  • They let you separate normal logic from error handling.
  • They help you find bugs faster with tracebacks.

docs.title: ✅ Common Built-in Exceptions
docs.text: Exception Typical Cause Example ValueError Wrong value type/format int("abc") TypeError Wrong operation for type "3" + 4 KeyError Missing dict key data["missing"] IndexError Invalid list index items[10] ZeroDivisionError Division by zero 10 / 0

docs.title: ✅ Raising Exceptions
docs.text:
You can raise your own exceptions to enforce rules:

def withdraw(balance, amount):
    if amount <= 0:
        raise ValueError("Amount must be positive")
    if amount > balance:
        raise ValueError("Insufficient funds")
    return balance - amount

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Exceptions are signals of failure with context.
  • Built-in exceptions cover most common errors.
  • Raising errors early prevents silent bugs.

Next: Try/Except/Finally →

docs.title: 🧠 Exceptions Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of exceptions and error signals.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the purpose of an exception?

  • A) Improve performance
  • B) Signal an error and stop incorrect execution
  • C) Replace functions
  • D) Hide bugs
Show Answer **B)** Exceptions signal failures and stop invalid execution paths.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which exception is raised by int("abc")?

  • A) TypeError
  • B) ValueError
  • C) KeyError
  • D) IndexError
Show Answer **B)** Invalid literal conversion raises `ValueError`.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does a stack trace show?

  • A) The list of variables in scope
  • B) The sequence of calls leading to an error
  • C) The memory layout of a program
  • D) The time complexity of functions
Show Answer **B)** A stack trace shows the call path to the error.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
When should you raise your own exceptions?

  • A) Never
  • B) Only in libraries
  • C) When input violates required rules
  • D) Only for type errors
Show Answer **C)** Raise errors when rules or invariants are broken.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which exception is most appropriate for a missing dictionary key?

  • A) KeyError
  • B) ValueError
  • C) ZeroDivisionError
  • D) AttributeError
Show Answer **A)** Missing dictionary keys raise `KeyError`.

Back to Exceptions README | Next: Try/Except/Finally →

docs.title: 🧯 Try / Except / Finally
docs.text: The try statement lets you separate normal logic from error handling. You can catch errors, run cleanup code, or execute alternative paths safely.

docs.title: ✅ Basic Pattern
docs.text:
try:
    value = int(user_input)
except ValueError:
    print("Please enter a number")

docs.title: ✅ else and finally
docs.text:
• else runs only if no exception happened.
  • finally runs always (success or failure), perfect for cleanup.
try:
    file = open("data.txt")
    data = file.read()
except FileNotFoundError:
    data = ""
else:
    print("Read successful")
finally:
    file.close()

docs.title: ✅ Catching Multiple Exceptions
docs.text:
try:
    result = data["count"] / total
except (KeyError, ZeroDivisionError) as exc:
    print("Problem:", exc)

docs.title: ⚠️ Don’t Catch Too Broadly
docs.text:
try:
    risky()
except Exception:
    pass  # hides bugs and makes debugging hard

Prefer catching specific errors you expect.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Use try/except to handle known failure cases.
  • Use else for success-only logic.
  • Use finally for cleanup and releasing resources.

Next: Custom Exceptions →

docs.title: 🧠 Try/Except/Finally Quiz
docs.text: Check your understanding of safe error handling flow.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does the finally block do?

  • A) Runs only if no error happens
  • B) Runs only if an error happens
  • C) Always runs, success or error
  • D) Stops exceptions from propagating
Show Answer **C)** `finally` executes regardless of success or failure.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
When does the else block run?

  • A) Only when an exception is raised
  • B) Only when no exception is raised
  • C) Always
  • D) Never
Show Answer **B)** `else` runs when the `try` block succeeds.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
Which is the best practice for except blocks?

  • A) Catch all exceptions with except Exception
  • B) Catch the most specific exception you expect
  • C) Always ignore exceptions
  • D) Use pass to hide errors
Show Answer **B)** Specific exceptions prevent hiding unrelated bugs.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What happens if you catch an exception and do nothing?

  • A) The program still crashes
  • B) The error is hidden and execution continues
  • C) Python restarts automatically
  • D) The exception becomes a warning
Show Answer **B)** Catching and ignoring hides the error.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Why is finally useful for files?

  • A) It speeds up file IO
  • B) It ensures files are closed even on errors
  • C) It prevents exceptions altogether
  • D) It changes file permissions
Show Answer **B)** `finally` guarantees cleanup.

Back to Try/Except/Finally README | Next: Custom Exceptions →

docs.title: 🧩 Custom Exceptions
docs.text: Custom exceptions let you describe errors in your own domain language. Instead of raising generic errors, you can create meaningful types that make debugging and handling clearer.

docs.title: ✅ Why Create Custom Exceptions?
docs.text:
• Clarity: InvalidEmailError is more meaningful than ValueError.
  • Control: Callers can catch specific error types.
  • Structure: You can build an error hierarchy.

docs.title: ✅ Defining a Custom Exception
docs.text:
class InvalidEmailError(ValueError):
    pass


def register(email):
    if "@" not in email:
        raise InvalidEmailError("Email must contain '@'")

docs.title: ✅ Exception Hierarchies
docs.text:
class PaymentError(Exception):
    pass


class CardDeclinedError(PaymentError):
    pass


class InsufficientFundsError(PaymentError):
    pass

Catch a whole category or a specific subtype:

try:
    charge(card)
except CardDeclinedError:
    handle_decline()
except PaymentError:
    handle_generic_payment_error()

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Custom exceptions improve readability and handling.
  • Inherit from a built-in exception when appropriate.
  • Use hierarchies for related error types.

Next: Defensive Programming →

docs.title: 🧠 Custom Exceptions Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of defining and using your own exceptions.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Why create custom exceptions?

  • A) To avoid writing tests
  • B) To make errors more meaningful and catchable
  • C) To speed up execution
  • D) To remove try/except blocks
Show Answer **B)** Custom exceptions improve clarity and handling.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is a good base class for a custom error about invalid input?

  • A) StopIteration
  • B) ValueError
  • C) ImportError
  • D) SystemExit
Show Answer **B)** Input validation errors typically subclass `ValueError`.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What is the advantage of an exception hierarchy?

  • A) It prevents exceptions from being raised
  • B) It lets you catch a group of related errors
  • C) It makes all errors identical
  • D) It removes the need for messages
Show Answer **B)** A hierarchy allows catching a whole category or a specific subtype.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Which code raises a custom exception?

  • A) raise InvalidEmailError("Missing @")
  • B) throw InvalidEmailError()
  • C) error InvalidEmailError()
  • D) InvalidEmailError.raise()
Show Answer **A)** Use `raise` to throw exceptions in Python.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Why should errors include clear messages?

  • A) To hide the real problem
  • B) To reduce logging
  • C) To make debugging faster
  • D) To avoid stack traces
Show Answer **C)** Clear messages speed up diagnosis and fixes.

Back to Custom Exceptions README | Next: Defensive Programming →

docs.title: 🛡️ Defensive Programming
docs.text: Defensive programming is about preventing errors before they happen. You validate inputs, check assumptions, and create clear guardrails so code fails fast and predictably.

docs.title: ✅ Common Defensive Techniques
docs.text:
• Input validation: check types, ranges, and formats.
  • Guard clauses: return early for invalid states.
  • Assertions: verify internal assumptions.
  • Defaults: provide safe fallbacks.

docs.title: ✅ Example: Guard Clauses
docs.text:
def transfer(balance, amount):
    if amount <= 0:
        raise ValueError("Amount must be positive")
    if amount > balance:
        raise ValueError("Insufficient funds")
    return balance - amount

docs.title: ✅ Assertions (Internal Checks)
docs.text:
def average(values):
    assert values, "values must not be empty"
    return sum(values) / len(values)

Use assertions for programmer errors, not user input.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Validate inputs early and clearly.
  • Guard clauses keep code readable.
  • Assertions document internal assumptions.

Next: Logging →

docs.title: 🧠 Defensive Programming Quiz
docs.text: Check your understanding of defensive techniques.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the main goal of defensive programming?

  • A) Make code shorter
  • B) Prevent errors before they happen
  • C) Avoid tests
  • D) Increase execution speed
Show Answer **B)** Defensive programming prevents failures with validation and guards.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is a guard clause?

  • A) A long if/else chain
  • B) An early return or raise for invalid states
  • C) A loop that checks each item
  • D) A global variable
Show Answer **B)** Guard clauses fail fast before the main logic runs.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
When should you use assertions?

  • A) For user input validation
  • B) For internal assumptions in code
  • C) To replace error handling
  • D) Only in production
Show Answer **B)** Assertions document and check developer assumptions.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What happens if an assertion fails?

  • A) The program ignores it
  • B) An AssertionError is raised
  • C) The program retries automatically
  • D) A warning is printed but continues
Show Answer **B)** Python raises `AssertionError`.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Which is a good defensive check for a percentage value?

  • A) value > 1000
  • B) 0 <= value <= 100
  • C) value == 50
  • D) value % 2 == 0
Show Answer **B)** Percentages should stay within 0 to 100.

Back to Defensive Programming README | Next: Logging →

docs.title: 🪵 Logging
docs.text: Logging records what happened and when so you can debug failures and understand system behavior. Unlike print, logs are structured, configurable, and can be stored in files or external systems.

docs.title: ✅ Why Logging Matters
docs.text:
• Debugging: See context around failures.
  • Monitoring: Track errors in production.
  • Auditing: Keep a record of important events.

docs.title: ✅ Basic Logging Example
docs.text:
import logging

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)

logging.info("App started")
logging.warning("Low disk space")
logging.error("Failed to connect to database")

docs.title: ✅ Logging Levels
docs.text: Level Use Case DEBUG Detailed diagnostic info INFO Normal events WARNING Unexpected, but not fatal ERROR Something failed CRITICAL App cannot continue

docs.title: ✅ Logging Exceptions
docs.text:
try:
    risky_operation()
except Exception:
    logging.exception("Something went wrong")

logging.exception records the traceback automatically.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Use logging instead of print for real applications.
  • Choose the right log level for each message.
  • Log exceptions with tracebacks for faster debugging.

Back: Defensive Programming ←

docs.title: 🧠 Logging Quiz
docs.text: Test your understanding of logging concepts.

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Why use logging instead of print in real applications?

  • A) Logging is faster than print in all cases
  • B) Logging is configurable and structured
  • C) Logging removes the need for tests
  • D) Logging prevents exceptions
Show Answer **B)** Logging supports levels, formats, and destinations.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which logging level is best for diagnostic details?

  • A) INFO
  • B) WARNING
  • C) DEBUG
  • D) CRITICAL
Show Answer **C)** `DEBUG` is used for detailed diagnostic information.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does logging.exception() do?

  • A) Suppresses the exception
  • B) Logs an error message with a traceback
  • C) Converts an exception to a warning
  • D) Stops the program immediately
Show Answer **B)** It logs the exception and includes the traceback.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Which level indicates a serious failure that may stop the program?

  • A) DEBUG
  • B) INFO
  • C) ERROR
  • D) CRITICAL
Show Answer **D)** `CRITICAL` is the highest severity.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What is a good message for a WARNING log?

  • A) "App started"
  • B) "Disk space low"
  • C) "User logged in"
  • D) "Sum = 3"
Show Answer **B)** Warnings indicate unusual or risky situations.

Back to Logging README

docs.title: ✅ Module 09: Testing
docs.text:
Testing is how we gain confidence that code works now and still works after changes. This module focuses on practical testing skills using Python's built-in unittest library and the popular third-party framework pytest.

Estimated Time: 8-10 hours \ Prerequisites: Module 01 (Foundations), Module 05 (Functional Programming) \ Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Why Testing What testing is and why it's valuable confidence, regression, fast feedback 02 Unit Testing Testing small units of logic arrange/act/assert, unittest, pytest 03 Test-Driven Development Writing tests before code red/green/refactor, small steps 04 Mocking Replacing slow/unreliable dependencies unittest.mock, stubs, fakes 05 Integration Testing Testing multiple components together boundaries, fixtures, test data

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Explain the difference between unit, integration, and end-to-end tests.
  • Write small, readable tests with clear assertions.
  • Use pytest basics (test functions, assertions, fixtures) and/or Python unittest.
  • Apply TDD to implement code in safe, incremental steps.
  • Use mocks for network/time/randomness/IO dependencies.

docs.title: 🧰 Recommended Setup (Optional)
docs.text:
This repo does not require extra dependencies, but if you want to use pytest:

pip install pytest

docs.title: 🧪 Why Testing?
docs.text: Testing is a way to prove (with executable checks) that your program behaves as expected. Good tests act like a safety net: you can change code and quickly detect regressions.

docs.title: ✅ What Testing Gives You
docs.text:
• Fast feedback: find bugs in seconds, not days.
  • Regression protection: if a bug comes back, tests catch it.
  • Better design: testable code tends to be modular and easier to reason about.
  • Living documentation: tests show how your code is intended to be used.

docs.title: ✅ Types of Tests (Typical Pyramid)
docs.text:
1. Unit tests
  2. Test small pieces (functions/classes)

  3. Fast, isolated, no network/files

  4. Integration tests

  5. Test multiple parts working together

  6. Example: read a file and parse JSON

  7. End-to-end (E2E) tests

  8. Test the whole system (UI/API + database)
  9. Slowest, most expensive to maintain

docs.title: ✅ What Makes a Test “Good”
docs.text:
• Readable: you understand what it checks in 10 seconds.
  • Deterministic: same result every run (no randomness/time/network).
  • Focused: one behavior per test.
  • Fast: the full suite should run quickly.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Tests help you ship changes with confidence.
  • Unit tests are the foundation; add integration tests at boundaries.
  • Deterministic and readable beats “clever”.

Next: Unit Testing →

docs.title: Quiz: Why Testing
docs.text:
1) What problem do regression tests prevent?

2) Name the three common test levels (unit/integration/...).

3) Why should tests be deterministic?

4) What is the Arrange / Act / Assert structure?

5) Give one example of a dependency that should usually be avoided in unit tests.

docs.title: ✅ Unit Testing
docs.text: Unit tests check small pieces of code in isolation. They should run fast and avoid external dependencies (network, filesystem, real time).

docs.title: 1) unittest (built-in)
docs.text:
• Comes with Python.
  • Uses test classes and methods.
  • Great when you can't install extra dependencies.

docs.title: 2) pytest (third-party)
docs.text:
• Very popular in the Python ecosystem.
  • Uses simple assert statements.
  • Excellent output and fixtures.

docs.title: ✅ Arrange / Act / Assert (AAA)
docs.text:
Most unit tests follow a simple pattern:

1) Arrange: set up inputs 2) Act: call the function 3) Assert: check the result

docs.title: ✅ What to Unit Test
docs.text:
• Business rules and pure logic
  • Edge cases (empty input, boundaries)
  • Error paths (invalid input)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Unit tests are the fastest and cheapest tests.
  • Keep unit tests independent and deterministic.
  • Prefer small functions with clear inputs/outputs.

Next: Test-Driven Development →

docs.title: Quiz: Unit Testing
docs.text:
1) What is a unit test supposed to isolate?

2) What does AAA stand for?

3) Why is using the real network in unit tests usually a bad idea?

4) In unittest, how do you assert that a function raises an exception?

5) In pytest, what keyword do you typically use for checks?

docs.title: 🔁 Test-Driven Development (TDD)
docs.text: TDD is a workflow where you write tests before implementation code. The goal is not "more tests", but better feedback and better design.

docs.title: ✅ The TDD Cycle: Red → Green → Refactor
docs.text: 1) Red: write a failing test that describes a small behavior 2) Green: implement the simplest code that makes the test pass 3) Refactor: improve code structure without changing behavior

docs.title: ✅ When TDD Helps Most
docs.text:
• Business logic with many edge cases
  • Code that should be stable over time
  • When you want confidence to refactor

docs.title: ⚠️ Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Writing huge tests first (too much at once)
  • Testing implementation details instead of behavior
  • Skipping refactoring (code becomes messy)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• TDD is about small steps.
  • Each test should add a new behavior.
  • Refactor with confidence after tests are green.

Next: Mocking →

docs.title: Quiz: TDD
docs.text:
1) What are the three steps in the TDD cycle?

2) In TDD, what should you do after all tests are green?

3) Why is it a bad idea to write many tests at once before implementing anything?

4) What does it mean to test behavior instead of implementation details?

5) Give one benefit of TDD beyond "catching bugs".

docs.title: 🎭 Mocking
docs.text:
Mocking is replacing a dependency with a controlled fake so your test can be:

  • Fast (no network/disk)
  • Deterministic (no randomness/time)
  • Focused (test only your logic)

In Python, the standard tool is unittest.mock.

docs.title: ✅ When to Mock
docs.text:
• External APIs / network calls
  • Current time (datetime.now())
  • Randomness (random.random())
  • Filesystem access
  • Slow functions

docs.title: ✅ What NOT to Mock (Usually)
docs.text:
• Your own logic (you want to test it)
  • Simple value objects
  • Too many internal calls (tests become brittle)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Mock the boundary, not the core logic.
  • Keep tests readable: the fake should be obvious.
  • If mocking gets complicated, consider redesigning.

Next: Integration Testing →

docs.title: Quiz: Mocking
docs.text:
1) What problem does mocking solve in unit tests?

2) Name two dependencies you commonly mock.

3) Why can too much mocking make tests brittle?

4) What is the difference between a mock and a stub (in spirit)?

5) Which Python standard library module provides mocking tools?

docs.title: 🔗 Integration Testing
docs.text:
Integration tests check that multiple parts work together. They typically cross a boundary: filesystem, database, HTTP, message queue, etc.

Unlike unit tests, integration tests may involve real IO, but should still:

  • be deterministic
  • clean up after themselves
  • be reasonably fast

docs.title: ✅ What to Integration-Test
docs.text:
• Reading/writing files and parsing
  • Calling a database layer
  • Using multiple modules together (e.g., parse + validate + transform)

docs.title: ✅ Good Practices
docs.text:
• Use temporary directories (tempfile) for filesystem tests
  • Keep test data small and obvious
  • Avoid global state; reset or isolate it

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Integration tests catch bugs that unit tests cannot (wrong wiring, wrong formats).
  • Keep them focused on boundaries.
  • Still prefer lots of fast unit tests, plus fewer integration tests.

docs.title: Quiz: Integration Testing
docs.text:
1) What is an integration test?

2) Give one example boundary that integration tests commonly cross.

3) Why are temporary directories useful in filesystem integration tests?

4) Why should integration tests still be deterministic?

5) Should you have more unit tests or integration tests in most projects? Why?

docs.title: 📁 Module 10: File & I/O
docs.text:
Files are how programs persist data and exchange information with the outside world. In Python, most file operations revolve around the built-in open() function and using context managers (with) to ensure files are closed properly.

Estimated Time: 4-6 hours \ Prerequisites: Module 01 (Foundations) \ Level: ⭐⭐ Beginner → Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Reading Files Open and read text safely encodings, iterating lines, with open(...) 02 Writing Files Create, overwrite, append modes (w, a), newline handling 03 Working with JSON Read/write structured data json.dumps, json.load, validation 04 Working with CSV Tabular data csv.reader, DictReader, DictWriter 05 Binary Files Read/write bytes rb/wb, hashing, chunked IO

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Read and write text files using a context manager.
  • Understand file modes (r, w, a, rb, wb) and when to use them.
  • Serialize/deserialize data using JSON.
  • Parse and generate CSV files in a platform-safe way (newline='').
  • Work with binary data and compute checksums/hashes efficiently.

docs.title: 📖 Reading Files
docs.text:
Reading files is a foundational I/O skill. The key idea is:

  • Use open() with a context manager (with) so the file closes automatically.
  • Specify an encoding for text files (UTF-8 is the modern default).

docs.title: ✅ Basic Pattern
docs.text:
with open("notes.txt", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    text = f.read()

docs.title: ✅ Common Reading Methods
docs.text: Method Returns When to use f.read() full file as a single string small/medium files f.readline() next line streaming line-by-line f.readlines() list of lines small files, quick processing for line in f: lines iterator large files, memory-safe

docs.title: ⚠️ Paths and Working Directory
docs.text: Relative paths are resolved from the current working directory (where you run python). If you need robust paths, consider pathlib.Path.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Prefer with open(...): to avoid leaking file handles.
  • Text files need an encoding; use encoding="utf-8".
  • Iterate over the file object for large files.

Back: Module 10 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Why is with open(...) as f: recommended?

  • A) It makes files load faster
  • B) It automatically closes the file even if an error happens
  • C) It prevents all exceptions
  • D) It encrypts the file
Show Answer **B)** The context manager closes the file reliably.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is the most memory-friendly way to process a huge text file?

  • A) f.read()
  • B) f.readlines()
  • C) for line in f:
  • D) json.load(f)
Show Answer **C)** Iterating line-by-line avoids loading the entire file at once.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does encoding="utf-8" affect?

  • A) How Python stores integers
  • B) How bytes are decoded into text (characters)
  • C) The file extension
  • D) The file permissions
Show Answer **B)** Encoding defines how to interpret bytes as characters.

Back to Reading Files README

docs.title: ✍️ Writing Files
docs.text: Writing files lets your program save results and create logs, reports, exports, and more.

docs.title: ✅ File Modes
docs.text:
Mode Meaning Notes "w" write (overwrite) creates file if missing "a" append writes at end, creates if missing "x" create exclusively fails if file exists "r+" read/write file must exist

For binary data use "wb" / "ab".

docs.title: ✅ Basic Pattern
docs.text:
with open("output.txt", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write("Hello!\n")

docs.title: ⚠️ Newlines on Windows
docs.text: Python will translate "\n" to the platform newline automatically for text files. For CSV, Python recommends newline='' when opening the file (covered in the CSV lesson).

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• "w" overwrites; "a" appends.
  • Use with so buffers flush and the file closes.
  • Prefer explicit UTF-8 encoding for text.

Back: Module 10 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does opening a file with mode "w" do?

  • A) It appends to the file
  • B) It overwrites the file (or creates it)
  • C) It reads the file only
  • D) It opens the file in binary mode
Show Answer **B)** `"w"` truncates the file to empty first (overwrite).

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why should you usually prefer with open(...) as f: when writing?

  • A) It makes writing faster
  • B) It ensures flushing/closing even on exceptions
  • C) It prevents the file from being created
  • D) It automatically encrypts the file
Show Answer **B)** It ensures data is flushed and file handles are released.

Back to Writing Files README

docs.title: 🧩 Working with JSON
docs.text: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a text-based format for structured data. In Python, you work with JSON via the built-in json module.

docs.title: ✅ JSON Basics
docs.text:
import json

data = {"name": "Ada", "age": 30, "skills": ["python", "math"]}

text = json.dumps(data)      # Python -> JSON string
obj = json.loads(text)       # JSON string -> Python

docs.title: ✅ JSON + Files
docs.text:
import json

with open("data.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(data, f, indent=2)

with open("data.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    loaded = json.load(f)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• JSON is text, but it represents nested structures.
  • Use json.dump/json.load for files (not dumps/loads).
  • Consider indent=2 for human-readable output.

Back: Module 10 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which function writes JSON to a file object?

  • A) json.dumps
  • B) json.dump
  • C) json.parse
  • D) json.load
Show Answer **B)** `json.dump(obj, file)` writes JSON to an open file handle.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is JSON best described as?

  • A) A binary format for images
  • B) A text format for structured data
  • C) A Python-only object format
  • D) A database engine
Show Answer **B)** JSON is human-readable text that represents nested structures.

Back to JSON README

docs.title: 📊 Working with CSV
docs.text: CSV (Comma-Separated Values) is a simple format for tabular data. Python's built-in csv module handles quoting and parsing correctly.

docs.title: ✅ Reading CSV
docs.text:
import csv

with open("people.csv", "r", encoding="utf-8", newline="") as f:
    reader = csv.DictReader(f)
    rows = list(reader)

docs.title: ✅ Writing CSV
docs.text:
import csv

rows = [{"name": "Ada", "age": "30"}]

with open("people.csv", "w", encoding="utf-8", newline="") as f:
    writer = csv.DictWriter(f, fieldnames=["name", "age"])
    writer.writeheader()
    writer.writerows(rows)

docs.title: ⚠️ Why newline=""?
docs.text: On Windows, not using newline="" can lead to extra blank lines in CSV output.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Use csv.reader for plain lists.
  • Use csv.DictReader/DictWriter for headers + dict rows.
  • Open CSV files with newline="".

Back: Module 10 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Why should CSV files usually be opened with newline=""?

  • A) It makes numbers parse correctly
  • B) It avoids extra blank lines on some platforms (especially Windows)
  • C) It automatically adds headers
  • D) It switches to binary mode
Show Answer **B)** The `csv` module expects `newline=""` to handle newlines consistently.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which reader is best when the CSV has headers?

  • A) csv.reader
  • B) csv.DictReader
  • C) csv.BinaryReader
  • D) csv.load
Show Answer **B)** `DictReader` maps each row to a dict using the header row.

Back to CSV README

docs.title: 🧱 Binary Files
docs.text: Binary files store raw bytes instead of text characters. Use binary modes "rb" and "wb" when working with images, PDFs, compressed data, or custom protocols.

docs.title: ✅ Reading/Writing Bytes
docs.text:
data = b"\x00\x01\x02"

with open("blob.bin", "wb") as f:
    f.write(data)

with open("blob.bin", "rb") as f:
    back = f.read()

docs.title: ✅ Chunked Reading (Large Files)
docs.text:
chunk_size = 8192
with open("big.bin", "rb") as f:
    while True:
        chunk = f.read(chunk_size)
        if not chunk:
            break
        # process chunk

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Text uses encodings; binary is raw bytes.
  • Use chunked IO for large files.
  • Hashing (like SHA-256) is a common binary-file operation.

Back: Module 10 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
Which mode should you use to read bytes from a file?

  • A) "r"
  • B) "rb"
  • C) "w"
  • D) "a"
Show Answer **B)** `"rb"` opens a file for reading in binary mode.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why use chunked reads when hashing a very large file?

  • A) It changes the hash result
  • B) It reduces memory usage
  • C) It makes the file smaller
  • D) It converts binary to text
Show Answer **B)** Chunking avoids loading the entire file into memory.

Back to Binary Files README

docs.title: 🧠 Module 11: Memory & Performance
docs.text:
Writing correct programs is step one. Writing programs that are fast enough and use memory efficiently is step two.

This module teaches the practical side of performance:

  • how Python stores objects in memory,
  • what “references” actually mean,
  • how to reason about time/space complexity,
  • and how to apply safe, measurable optimizations.

Estimated Time: 8-10 hours \ Prerequisites: Module 02 (Data Structures), Module 03 (Algorithms) \ Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Memory Basics How Python represents objects id(), mutability, GC, memoryview 02 References vs Values Aliasing and copying shallow vs deep copy, copy module 03 Time Complexity Reason about runtime growth linear vs quadratic, sets vs lists 04 Space Complexity Reason about memory usage in-place, recursion stack, generators 05 Big-O Notation Analyze algorithms consistently common Big-O classes, tradeoffs 06 Optimization Techniques Make code faster safely profiling, caching, built-ins

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Explain how Python uses object references and why “assignment doesn’t copy”.
  • Predict how runtime changes when input size grows (Big-O).
  • Choose data structures with appropriate performance characteristics.
  • Identify “slow” patterns (nested loops, repeated work, unnecessary copies).
  • Apply optimizations only after measuring.

docs.title: 🧩 Memory Basics
docs.text:
Python programs manipulate objects. Variables don’t “contain” the object — they refer to it.

This topic focuses on:

  • object identity: id()
  • mutability vs immutability
  • avoiding unnecessary copies using memoryview

docs.title: ✅ Object Identity & References
docs.text:
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = a

print(id(a) == id(b))  # True (same object)

a and b are two names pointing to the same list.

docs.title: ✅ Mutability
docs.text:
• Mutable objects can change “in place” (list, dict, set).
  • Immutable objects can’t (int, float, str, tuple). “Changing” them creates a new object.

docs.title: ✅ Views with memoryview
docs.text: If you slice bytes, you often create a copy. With memoryview(), you can create a view into the same underlying buffer.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Variables hold references to objects.
  • Mutability decides whether changes affect the same object.
  • memoryview helps avoid copies for binary data.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
In Python, what does assigning b = a (for a list) do?

  • A) Creates a deep copy of the list
  • B) Creates a shallow copy of the list
  • C) Makes b refer to the same list object
  • D) Converts the list to a tuple
Show Answer **C)** `b` becomes another reference to the same object.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why might you use memoryview with bytes?

  • A) To automatically compress data
  • B) To avoid copying when slicing/processing binary data
  • C) To convert bytes into a string
  • D) To increase recursion depth
Show Answer **B)** `memoryview` can create a view into the same buffer without copying.

Back to Memory Basics README

docs.title: 🔗 References vs Values
docs.text:
In Python, assignment does not copy. It binds a name to an object.

This can be surprising with mutable objects:

a = [1, 2]
b = a
b.append(3)

print(a)  # [1, 2, 3]

docs.title: ✅ Shallow vs Deep Copy
docs.text:
• Shallow copy copies the container, but keeps references to the same inner objects.
  • Deep copy recursively copies inner objects too.
import copy

nested = [[1], [2]]
shallow = copy.copy(nested)
deep = copy.deepcopy(nested)

docs.title: ✅ When to Copy
docs.text:
Copy when:

  • you want to prevent accidental mutation via aliases
  • you need an independent version to modify

Avoid copying when:

  • the object is large and you only need read access
  • you can use an immutable type (tuple, frozenset, etc.)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Python variables hold references.
  • Mutations affect all references to the same object.
  • Use shallow/deep copies intentionally.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the difference between a shallow and a deep copy?

  • A) Shallow copies are always faster and always safe
  • B) Shallow copy duplicates inner objects; deep copy does not
  • C) Shallow copy copies only the outer container; deep copy copies nested objects too
  • D) There is no difference in Python
Show Answer **C)** Shallow copies keep references to the same inner objects.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
If two variables reference the same list, what happens when you append() through one variable?

  • A) Only that variable changes
  • B) Both “see” the change because it is the same object
  • C) Python raises an error
  • D) The list is automatically copied
Show Answer **B)** Mutation affects the single shared list object.

Back to References vs Values README

docs.title: ⏱️ Time Complexity
docs.text:
Time complexity describes how runtime grows as input size grows.

You usually care about the shape of the growth, not the exact milliseconds.

docs.title: ✅ Common Patterns
docs.text: Pattern Example Typical Big-O Constant Access arr[0] O(1) Linear Loop over list O(n) Quadratic Nested loops over list O(n^2) Logarithmic Binary search O(log n)

docs.title: ✅ Data Structures Matter
docs.text:
Checking membership:

target in some_list  # O(n)
target in some_set   # O(1) average

Same problem, different runtime.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Focus on growth trends (n, n^2, log n).
  • Use sets/dicts for fast membership when appropriate.
  • Avoid unnecessary nested loops.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the typical time complexity of checking x in some_list?

  • A) O(1)
  • B) O(log n)
  • C) O(n)
  • D) O(n^2)
Show Answer **C)** Lists use a linear scan for membership.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What is the typical average time complexity of checking x in some_set?

  • A) O(1)
  • B) O(n)
  • C) O(n log n)
  • D) O(n^2)
Show Answer **A)** Sets use hashing, giving `O(1)` average membership checks.

Back to Time Complexity README

docs.title: 🧳 Space Complexity
docs.text:
Space complexity describes how much extra memory an algorithm uses as input grows.

Important idea: distinguish between:

  • input space (the data you already have)
  • auxiliary space (extra memory the algorithm allocates)

docs.title: ✅ Common Space Patterns
docs.text:
• Building a new list of size n → O(n) extra space
  • Using a few variables → O(1) extra space
  • Recursion adds call stack frames → often O(depth)

docs.title: ✅ Generators vs Lists
docs.text:
squares_list = [x * x for x in range(1_000_000)]  # stores everything
squares_gen = (x * x for x in range(1_000_000))   # computes one at a time

Generators often reduce memory usage because they don’t store all results at once.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Favor in-place operations when safe.
  • Prefer generators for streaming data.
  • Remember recursion uses stack memory.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is a typical memory advantage of using a generator instead of building a list?

  • A) It makes the CPU faster by default
  • B) It stores fewer results in memory at once
  • C) It changes O(n) time to O(1) time
  • D) It automatically parallelizes computation
Show Answer **B)** Generators yield items one at a time instead of storing all items.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What extra space does an in-place algorithm often aim for?

  • A) O(n)
  • B) O(n^2)
  • C) O(1)
  • D) O(log n)
Show Answer **C)** In-place usually targets constant auxiliary space.

Back to Space Complexity README

docs.title: 📈 Big-O Notation
docs.text:
Big-O is a way to describe how runtime (or memory) grows with input size n.

It ignores constant factors and focuses on long-term growth.

docs.title: ✅ Common Big-O Classes
docs.text: Big-O Name Example O(1) constant dict/set membership (average) O(log n) logarithmic binary search O(n) linear scanning a list O(n log n) linearithmic merge sort O(n^2) quadratic nested loops over list

docs.title: ✅ How to Analyze
docs.text:
• Loops add up: for over n → O(n)
  • Nested loops multiply: n inside n → O(n^2)
  • Sequential steps: keep the dominant term: O(n) + O(n^2) → O(n^2)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Big-O is about growth, not exact time.
  • Use it to compare approaches.
  • Don’t guess: reason about loops, recursion, and data structure operations.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the Big-O time complexity of binary search on a sorted list?

  • A) O(1)
  • B) O(log n)
  • C) O(n)
  • D) O(n^2)
Show Answer **B)** Binary search halves the search space each step.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which Big-O class grows fastest as n becomes very large?

  • A) O(n)
  • B) O(log n)
  • C) O(n log n)
  • D) O(n^2)
Show Answer **D)** Quadratic growth dominates linear and linearithmic growth for large `n`.

Back to Big-O Notation README

docs.title: ⚙️ Optimization Techniques
docs.text:
Optimization is a skill — and a trap.

The best workflow is:

  1. Make it correct.
  2. Measure.
  3. Improve the bottleneck.
  4. Measure again.

docs.title: 1) Use the right data structure
docs.text:
• list membership: O(n)
  • set/dict membership: O(1) average

docs.title: 2) Avoid repeated work
docs.text: Cache results when inputs repeat.

docs.title: 3) Prefer built-ins
docs.text: Built-ins like sum, sorted, "".join are implemented in optimized C.

docs.title: 4) Profile before guessing
docs.text:
• timeit for micro-benchmarks
  • cProfile for bigger programs
  • tracemalloc for memory investigations

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Measure first.
  • Optimize the bottleneck, not the code you “feel” is slow.
  • Prefer readability until performance is proven to be a problem.

Back: Module 11 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is usually the best first step before optimizing code?

  • A) Rewrite everything in a different language
  • B) Add caching everywhere
  • C) Measure and identify the bottleneck
  • D) Remove all comments
Show Answer **C)** Profiling/measurement tells you what is actually slow.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Why is "".join(parts) typically faster than repeated string concatenation in a loop?

  • A) It uses less CPU because it skips checks
  • B) It is implemented in optimized C and avoids many intermediate strings
  • C) It automatically compresses the output
  • D) It changes Big-O from O(n) to O(1)
Show Answer **B)** Joining avoids creating many temporary strings.

Back to Optimization Techniques README

docs.title: ⚡ Module 12: Concurrency
docs.text:
Concurrency is about doing multiple things at once (or at least overlapping their progress).

In Python, concurrency usually shows up in three practical forms:

  • Threads (threading, concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor) for I/O-bound work
  • Async (asyncio) for high-concurrency I/O without many OS threads
  • Processes (multiprocessing, ProcessPoolExecutor) for CPU-bound parallelism (briefly mentioned)

Estimated Time: 10-12 hours \ Prerequisites: Modules 01-05 \ Level: ⭐⭐⭐⭐ Advanced

docs.text:

  • Choose between threads and async based on the problem.
  • Protect shared state with the right synchronization primitive.
  • Explain what a race condition is and how to prevent it.
  • Recognize and avoid common deadlock patterns.
  • Write concurrent code that is correct, testable, and maintainable.

docs.title: 🧵 Threads Basics
docs.text:
A thread is an OS-level unit of execution inside a process. Multiple threads share the same memory, which makes communication easy—but also makes bugs (like races) easy.

Python threads are most useful for I/O-bound work:

  • waiting for network responses
  • reading/writing files
  • calling slow APIs

For CPU-bound work, Python’s GIL (Global Interpreter Lock) often prevents threads from running Python bytecode in parallel. In those cases, prefer processes.

docs.title: ✅ Creating and Joining Threads
docs.text:
import threading

def worker():
    print("Hello from a thread")

t = threading.Thread(target=worker)
t.start()
t.join()
  • start() begins running the thread.
  • join() waits for it to finish.

docs.title: ✅ Thread Pools
docs.text:
For many small tasks, use a thread pool:

  • concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor
  • executor.submit(...) / executor.map(...)

Thread pools manage thread creation and reuse for you.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Threads overlap work, especially when waiting on I/O.
  • Always join() (or use a pool) when you need results.
  • Be careful with shared state—synchronization comes next.

Back: Module 12 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does thread.join() do?

  • A) Starts a thread
  • B) Stops a thread immediately
  • C) Waits for a thread to finish
  • D) Makes a thread run faster
Show Answer **C)** `join()` blocks until the thread completes.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
When are Python threads usually most beneficial?

  • A) CPU-heavy math and image processing
  • B) I/O-bound work (waiting on network/files)
  • C) Replacing all for-loops
  • D) Increasing recursion depth
Show Answer **B)** Threads help overlap waiting on I/O.

Back to Threads Basics README

docs.title: 🔒 Synchronization
docs.text:
Threads share memory, which means two threads can read/write the same data at the same time.

Synchronization primitives help you coordinate access and avoid corruption.

docs.title: ✅ Locks
docs.text:
A Lock protects a critical section:

import threading

lock = threading.Lock()

with lock:
    # only one thread at a time here
    shared_counter += 1

Use the smallest critical section possible.

docs.title: ✅ Events
docs.text:
An Event is a simple signal:

  • one thread waits: event.wait()
  • another thread signals: event.set()

docs.title: ✅ Semaphores
docs.text: A Semaphore limits how many threads may enter a section concurrently.

docs.title: ✅ Prefer Message Passing
docs.text:
Often the cleanest approach is to avoid sharing state:

  • use queue.Queue to pass work/results between threads
  • let each thread own its local state

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Use Lock when you must share state.
  • Use Event for one-way signaling.
  • Use Queue to reduce shared-state complexity.

Back: Module 12 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What problem does a Lock primarily solve?

  • A) It makes code run faster
  • B) It prevents two threads from entering a critical section at the same time
  • C) It automatically retries failed network calls
  • D) It creates new threads
Show Answer **B)** A lock provides mutual exclusion for shared state.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which primitive is best for simple one-way signaling between threads?

  • A) threading.Event
  • B) threading.RLock
  • C) threading.Barrier
  • D) threading.local
Show Answer **A)** An `Event` is designed for signaling.

Back to Synchronization README

docs.title: 🌐 Async Programming (asyncio)
docs.text:
asyncio provides concurrency via cooperative multitasking:

  • code runs in a single OS thread
  • tasks voluntarily yield control at await
  • great for "lots of I/O" workloads (many sockets, many requests)

Async is not automatically faster—it’s a tool for scaling I/O concurrency while keeping code readable.

docs.title: ✅ Coroutines and await
docs.text:
import asyncio

async def say_after(delay: float, msg: str) -> None:
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    print(msg)

asyncio.run(say_after(1.0, "hello"))

docs.title: ✅ Tasks and gather()
docs.text:
• asyncio.create_task(...) schedules a coroutine.
  • asyncio.gather(...) waits for many tasks and returns results.

docs.title: ✅ Limiting Concurrency
docs.text: Even in async code you sometimes need to limit parallel work (e.g. 1000 requests at once is still too many). Use an asyncio.Semaphore.

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• async/await is for high-concurrency I/O.
  • await is where other tasks can run.
  • Use tasks + gather() to run many coroutines.

Back: Module 12 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
In asyncio, when can other tasks run?

  • A) Only when you call print()
  • B) At await points
  • C) Only when the program exits
  • D) When you create a new thread
Show Answer **B)** Tasks switch at `await` points.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does asyncio.gather() return?

  • A) A list of results from awaited coroutines
  • B) A new OS thread
  • C) A file handle
  • D) A lock
Show Answer **A)** It waits for all provided awaitables and returns their results.

Back to Async Programming README

docs.title: 🏁 Race Conditions
docs.text:
A race condition happens when the correctness of your program depends on timing.

Typical pattern:

  1. Thread A reads shared state
  2. Thread B changes it
  3. Thread A writes back using stale information

Even with the GIL, many multi-step operations ("read-modify-write") are not atomic.

docs.title: ✅ Classic Example: Shared Counter
docs.text:
Two threads both run:

counter = counter + 1

That statement is multiple bytecode operations: load, add, store. Another thread can interleave between those steps.

docs.title: ✅ Fixes
docs.text:
• Protect the critical section with threading.Lock
  • Avoid shared mutable state (message passing, queue.Queue)
  • Use higher-level primitives (thread-safe queues, executors)

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• A race condition is a correctness bug, not just "weird behavior".
  • If you share state, you need a strategy: lock, queue, or redesign.

Back: Module 12 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is a race condition?

  • A) A program that runs too fast
  • B) A bug where correctness depends on timing/interleaving
  • C) A type of syntax error
  • D) A thread that never starts
Show Answer **B)** Races depend on timing and interleaving.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which is a common way to prevent races on shared state?

  • A) Use a Lock around the critical section
  • B) Add more print() statements
  • C) Use break in loops
  • D) Turn the code into a class
Show Answer **A)** Locks provide mutual exclusion.

Back to Race Conditions README

docs.title: 🪢 Deadlocks
docs.text:
A deadlock is when two or more threads wait forever because each is holding a resource the other needs.

Classic scenario:

  • Thread A holds Lock 1 and waits for Lock 2
  • Thread B holds Lock 2 and waits for Lock 1

No one can proceed.

docs.title: ✅ How Deadlocks Happen
docs.text:
Deadlocks usually appear when:

  • you hold multiple locks at once
  • different code paths acquire locks in different orders

docs.title: ✅ Prevention Strategies
docs.text:
• Lock ordering: always acquire multiple locks in a consistent order
  • Timeouts: use lock.acquire(timeout=...) and back off
  • Reduce shared state: fewer locks, fewer problems
  • Use higher-level designs: queues, actors, single owner of state

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Deadlocks are often caused by inconsistent lock ordering.
  • The simplest fix is often a design fix (reduce lock sharing).

Back: Module 12 README

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is a deadlock?

  • A) A thread that runs too quickly
  • B) Two threads waiting forever due to circular resource dependency
  • C) A syntax error in multithreaded code
  • D) A missing import
Show Answer **B)** Deadlocks commonly happen when locks are acquired in inconsistent order.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
A common deadlock prevention strategy is:

  • A) Acquiring locks in a consistent global order
  • B) Using more threads
  • C) Calling join() less often
  • D) Converting lists to tuples
Show Answer **A)** Lock ordering prevents circular wait.

Back to Deadlocks README

docs.title: 📦 Module 13: Modules & Packages
docs.text:
As your Python projects grow, you need to organize code into reusable, maintainable pieces. This module teaches you how Python's module and package system works.

In Python: - A module is a single .py file containing definitions - A package is a directory of modules with an __init__.py - Virtual environments isolate project dependencies - Dependency management tracks what packages your project needs

Estimated Time: 6-8 hours Prerequisites: Modules 01-05 Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Intermediate

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Understand the import system and how Python finds modules.
  • Create your own reusable modules with clean APIs.
  • Structure larger projects using packages.
  • Set up and use virtual environments for project isolation.
  • Manage dependencies effectively with pip and requirements files.

docs.title: 🔗 Why This Matters
docs.text:
Real-world Python projects are rarely single files. You need:

  • Code reuse - Don't repeat yourself across files
  • Organization - Group related functionality together
  • Isolation - Keep project dependencies separate
  • Reproducibility - Others can install the same packages

This module teaches the standard Python practices used in professional development.

Start here: 01_imports

docs.title: 📥 Imports
docs.text: The import system is how Python finds and loads code from other files. Understanding imports is essential for organizing larger projects.

docs.title: ✅ Basic Import Syntax
docs.text:
# Import the whole module
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0

# Import specific names
from math import sqrt, pi
print(sqrt(16))  # 4.0

# Import with alias
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime as dt

docs.title: ✅ What Happens During Import
docs.text:
When you import a module, Python:

  1. Searches for the module in sys.path
  2. Compiles the .py file to bytecode (cached in __pycache__)
  3. Executes the module code once
  4. Caches the module in sys.modules

Subsequent imports of the same module use the cached version.

docs.title: ✅ The Search Path (sys.path)
docs.text:
Python looks for modules in this order:

import sys
print(sys.path)
# ['', '/usr/lib/python3.x', '/usr/lib/python3.x/site-packages', ...]
  1. Current directory (or script directory)
  2. PYTHONPATH environment variable directories
  3. Standard library directories
  4. Site-packages (installed packages)

docs.title: ✅ Import Styles
docs.text:
# Style 1: Import module (preferred for large modules)
import os
os.path.join("a", "b")  # Clear where join comes from

# Style 2: Import specific names (good for frequently used items)
from os.path import join, exists
join("a", "b")  # Shorter, but origin less clear

# Style 3: Import all (generally avoid)
from os.path import *  # Pollutes namespace, hard to track origins

docs.title: ✅ Common Import Patterns
docs.text:
# Standard library first, then third-party, then local
import os
import sys

import requests
import numpy as np

from myproject import utils
from myproject.models import User

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• import module vs from module import name have different use cases.
  • Python caches imports in sys.modules for efficiency.
  • The search path (sys.path) determines where Python looks for modules.
  • Follow PEP 8 import ordering: stdlib, third-party, local.

Back: Module 13 README | Next: Creating Modules

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the difference between import math and from math import sqrt?

  • A) No difference, they work exactly the same
  • B) import math loads the whole module; from math import sqrt loads only sqrt
  • C) import math creates a namespace; from math import sqrt adds sqrt directly to current namespace
  • D) from math import sqrt is faster because it loads less code
Show Answer **C)** Both load the entire module, but `import math` keeps it in the `math` namespace (access via `math.sqrt`), while `from math import sqrt` binds `sqrt` directly in the current namespace.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Where does Python look first when you import mymodule?

  • A) The standard library
  • B) Site-packages directory
  • C) The current directory (or script's directory)
  • D) PYTHONPATH environment variable
Show Answer **C)** Python checks the current directory first, then PYTHONPATH, then standard library, then site-packages.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What does sys.modules contain?

  • A) List of all available modules
  • B) Cache of already imported modules
  • C) List of module search paths
  • D) Configuration for the import system
Show Answer **B)** `sys.modules` is a dictionary that caches all modules that have been imported, so subsequent imports use the cached version.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Why is from module import * generally discouraged?

  • A) It's slower than other import styles
  • B) It pollutes the namespace and makes it hard to track where names come from
  • C) It doesn't work with third-party packages
  • D) It imports too little code
Show Answer **B)** Star imports bring all public names into your namespace, making it unclear where functions come from and potentially causing name collisions.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What happens if you import the same module twice?

  • A) The module code runs twice
  • B) Python raises an ImportError
  • C) The second import uses the cached version from sys.modules
  • D) The second import overwrites the first
Show Answer **C)** Python caches modules in `sys.modules` after the first import. Subsequent imports return the cached module without re-executing the code.

Back to Imports README

docs.title: 🔧 Creating Modules
docs.text: A module is simply a Python file (.py) containing definitions and statements. Creating your own modules lets you organize and reuse code.

docs.title: ✅ Basic Module Structure
docs.text:
# mymodule.py

"""Module docstring describing what this module does."""

# Constants
DEFAULT_TIMEOUT = 30

# Functions
def greet(name: str) -> str:
    """Return a greeting message."""
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

# Classes
class Calculator:
    """A simple calculator."""
    def add(self, a: int, b: int) -> int:
        return a + b

docs.title: ✅ The __name__ Variable
docs.text:
Every module has a __name__ attribute:

# mymodule.py
print(f"Module name: {__name__}")

def main():
    print("Running as main program")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
  • When run directly: __name__ is "__main__"
  • When imported: __name__ is the module name (e.g., "mymodule")

This pattern lets files work both as importable modules AND as runnable scripts.

docs.title: ✅ Controlling Public API with __all__
docs.text:
# mymodule.py

__all__ = ["public_function", "PublicClass"]

def public_function():
    """This is part of the public API."""
    pass

def _private_helper():
    """Convention: underscore prefix = internal use."""
    pass

class PublicClass:
    pass

class _InternalClass:
    pass
  • __all__ defines what from module import * includes
  • Names starting with _ are conventionally private
  • Users can still import private names explicitly

docs.title: ✅ Module-Level Code
docs.text:
Code at the module level runs once during import:

# config.py

import os

# This runs when the module is imported
DATABASE_URL = os.environ.get("DATABASE_URL", "sqlite:///default.db")

def get_connection():
    return connect(DATABASE_URL)

Be careful with module-level code that has side effects!

docs.title: ✅ Module Design Guidelines
docs.text:
1. One clear purpose - Each module should do one thing well
  2. Clean public API - Use __all__ and _ prefixes
  3. Minimal dependencies - Import only what you need
  4. Document - Add docstrings for module and public items
  5. Avoid side effects - Module code shouldn't modify global state

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• A module is just a .py file with definitions.
  • Use if __name__ == "__main__": for script/module dual use.
  • __all__ defines the public API for star imports.
  • Keep modules focused on a single responsibility.

Back: Imports | Next: Packages

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the value of __name__ when a Python file is run directly (not imported)?

  • A) The filename without .py
  • B) "__main__"
  • C) "module"
  • D) None
Show Answer **B)** When a file is run directly, `__name__` is set to `"__main__"`. When imported, it's set to the module name.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does __all__ control in a module?

  • A) Which functions can be called
  • B) What gets imported with from module import *
  • C) Which names are visible to other modules
  • D) What shows up in dir(module)
Show Answer **B)** `__all__` is a list that defines what names are exported when someone uses `from module import *`. It doesn't prevent direct imports of other names.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What naming convention indicates a name is "private" in Python?

  • A) Using the private keyword
  • B) Starting with double underscore __
  • C) Starting with single underscore _
  • D) Ending with underscore _
Show Answer **C)** A single leading underscore (e.g., `_helper`) is the convention for private/internal names. Double underscores trigger name mangling in classes, which is different.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
When does module-level code execute?

  • A) Every time the module is imported
  • B) Only when the module is run directly
  • C) Once, the first time the module is imported
  • D) Never, only function code executes
Show Answer **C)** Module-level code runs once during the first import. Subsequent imports use the cached module from `sys.modules`.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Why use if __name__ == "__main__": at the end of a module?

  • A) To make the code run faster
  • B) To hide implementation details
  • C) To allow the file to work both as a script and as an importable module
  • D) To prevent syntax errors
Show Answer **C)** This pattern lets you put script code (tests, demos, CLI) that only runs when the file is executed directly, while still allowing the file to be imported as a module without running that code.

Back to Creating Modules README

docs.title: 📁 Packages
docs.text: A package is a directory containing Python modules and a special __init__.py file. Packages help organize larger projects into hierarchical namespaces.

docs.title: ✅ Package Structure
docs.text:
mypackage/
├── __init__.py          # Makes this directory a package
├── module1.py
├── module2.py
└── subpackage/
    ├── __init__.py
    └── module3.py

docs.title: ✅ The __init__.py File
docs.text:
The __init__.py file: - Makes a directory a Python package - Runs when the package is imported - Can be empty or contain initialization code

# mypackage/__init__.py

"""MyPackage - A sample package."""

__version__ = "1.0.0"

# Import commonly used items for convenience
from .module1 import important_function
from .module2 import UsefulClass

__all__ = ["important_function", "UsefulClass", "module1", "module2"]

docs.title: ✅ Importing from Packages
docs.text:
# Import the package
import mypackage
mypackage.important_function()

# Import a module from the package
from mypackage import module1
module1.some_function()

# Import specific items
from mypackage.module1 import some_function

# Import from subpackage
from mypackage.subpackage import module3
from mypackage.subpackage.module3 import deep_function

docs.title: ✅ Relative Imports
docs.text:
Inside a package, use relative imports with dots:

# mypackage/module2.py

# Import from same package (one dot)
from . import module1
from .module1 import helper_function

# Import from parent package (two dots)
from .. import parent_module
from ..sibling_package import other_module
  • . means current package
  • .. means parent package
  • Only works inside packages (not in scripts run directly)

docs.title: ✅ Namespace Packages (Python 3.3+)
docs.text:
Packages without __init__.py are namespace packages. They allow splitting a package across multiple directories:

location1/
└── mypkg/
    └── module_a.py

location2/
└── mypkg/
    └── module_b.py

# Both contribute to the same 'mypkg' namespace
import mypkg.module_a
import mypkg.module_b

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Packages are directories with __init__.py
  • Use __init__.py to define package-level imports and __all__
  • Relative imports (., ..) work within packages
  • Organize large projects into logical package hierarchies

Back: Creating Modules | Next: Virtual Environments

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What makes a directory a Python package?

  • A) Having at least one .py file
  • B) Having a setup.py file
  • C) Having an __init__.py file
  • D) Being listed in sys.path
Show Answer **C)** A directory becomes a package when it contains an `__init__.py` file (which can be empty). Python 3.3+ also supports namespace packages without `__init__.py`, but traditional packages require it.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does a relative import like from ..utils import helper mean?

  • A) Import from the current directory's utils module
  • B) Import from the parent package's utils module
  • C) Import from the utils package in site-packages
  • D) Import from a module two levels up in the file system
Show Answer **B)** Two dots (`..`) mean "go up one package level." So from `myapp.sub.module`, `..utils` resolves to `myapp.utils`.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
When does the code in __init__.py execute?

  • A) When Python starts
  • B) When any module in the package is imported
  • C) When the package itself is imported
  • D) Only when explicitly called
Show Answer **C)** `__init__.py` executes when you import the package (e.g., `import mypackage`). Importing a submodule also triggers it if the package wasn't already imported.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
How can you tell if an imported module is a package or a regular module?

  • A) Packages have __package__ attribute, modules don't
  • B) Packages have __path__ attribute, regular modules don't
  • C) Packages have a .pkg extension
  • D) Check if type(module) == 'package'
Show Answer **B)** Packages have a `__path__` attribute (a list of paths where submodules can be found). Regular modules don't have this attribute.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
Why would you define imports in __init__.py?

  • A) To make the package load faster
  • B) To hide implementation details and provide a clean public API
  • C) It's required for the package to work
  • D) To prevent circular imports
Show Answer **B)** By importing key items in `__init__.py`, you let users write `from mypackage import Thing` instead of `from mypackage.deep.module import Thing`. This creates a cleaner API and hides internal structure.

Back to Packages README

docs.title: 🏠 Virtual Environments
docs.text: A virtual environment is an isolated Python installation that keeps project dependencies separate from other projects and the system Python.

docs.title: ✅ Why Virtual Environments?
docs.text:
Without virtual environments: - Project A needs requests==2.25.0 - Project B needs requests==2.28.0 - Conflict! Only one version can be installed globally.

With virtual environments: - Each project has its own isolated site-packages - No conflicts between projects - Reproducible installations

docs.title: ✅ Creating a Virtual Environment
docs.text:
# Using the built-in venv module (recommended)
python -m venv myenv

# Creates a directory structure:
# myenv/
# ├── bin/           (or Scripts/ on Windows)
# ├── include/
# ├── lib/
# └── pyvenv.cfg

docs.title: ✅ Activating and Deactivating
docs.text:
# Linux/macOS
source myenv/bin/activate

# Windows (PowerShell)
myenv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

# Windows (CMD)
myenv\Scripts\activate.bat

# Deactivate (any platform)
deactivate

When activated: - python points to the venv's Python - pip install installs to the venv's site-packages - Your prompt usually shows (myenv) prefix

docs.title: ✅ Checking Your Environment
docs.text:
# See which Python is active
which python        # Linux/macOS
where python        # Windows

# Check the environment
python -c "import sys; print(sys.prefix)"

# List installed packages
pip list

docs.title: ✅ Project Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Create venv in project folder
cd myproject
python -m venv .venv

# 2. Activate it
source .venv/bin/activate  # or Windows equivalent

# 3. Install dependencies
pip install requests flask

# 4. Save dependencies
pip freeze > requirements.txt

# 5. Work on your project
python app.py

# 6. Deactivate when done
deactivate

docs.title: ✅ Common Conventions
docs.text:
• Name: .venv or venv (dot prefix hides it on Unix)
  • Location: Inside the project directory
  • Git: Add .venv/ to .gitignore (don't commit it!)
  • Always use a venv per project

docs.title: ✅ Alternatives to venv
docs.text: Tool Description venv Built-in, simple, recommended for most cases virtualenv Third-party, more features, faster conda Full environment manager, great for data science pyenv Manages multiple Python versions poetry Modern dependency + venv management

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Always use virtual environments for Python projects.
  • python -m venv .venv creates an isolated environment.
  • Activate before installing packages, deactivate when done.
  • Add .venv/ to .gitignore.

Back: Packages | Next: Dependency Management

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What is the main purpose of a virtual environment?

  • A) To make Python run faster
  • B) To isolate project dependencies from other projects
  • C) To enable multiple Python versions on one system
  • D) To protect code from viruses
Show Answer **B)** Virtual environments isolate project dependencies, so each project can have its own versions of packages without conflicts.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
Which command creates a virtual environment using Python's built-in module?

  • A) pip install venv myenv
  • B) python -m venv myenv
  • C) virtualenv create myenv
  • D) python --venv myenv
Show Answer **B)** `python -m venv myenv` uses the built-in `venv` module to create a virtual environment in the `myenv` directory.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
How can you tell if you're inside an activated virtual environment?

  • A) sys.prefix == sys.base_prefix
  • B) sys.prefix != sys.base_prefix
  • C) Check if python --version works
  • D) Look for a venv folder in your home directory
Show Answer **B)** When in a venv, `sys.prefix` (current environment) differs from `sys.base_prefix` (base Python installation).

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
What should you do with the virtual environment directory when using Git?

  • A) Commit it to track exact dependencies
  • B) Add it to .gitignore and use requirements.txt instead
  • C) Compress it before committing
  • D) Store it in a separate branch
Show Answer **B)** Virtual environments are large and platform-specific. Add `.venv/` to `.gitignore` and track dependencies in `requirements.txt` or `pyproject.toml` instead.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What does the pyvenv.cfg file contain?

  • A) A list of installed packages
  • B) Python source code
  • C) Configuration about the virtual environment (base Python path, version)
  • D) Activation scripts
Show Answer **C)** `pyvenv.cfg` contains metadata about the venv, including the path to the base Python interpreter and whether system site-packages are included.

Back to Virtual Environments README

docs.title: 📋 Dependency Management
docs.text: Dependency management is how you track, install, and update the external packages your project needs. Good dependency management ensures reproducible builds.

docs.title: ✅ pip - The Package Installer
docs.text:
# Install a package
pip install requests

# Install a specific version
pip install requests==2.28.0

# Install with version constraints
pip install "requests>=2.25.0,<3.0.0"

# Install from requirements file
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Show installed packages
pip list

# Show package info
pip show requests

# Uninstall a package
pip uninstall requests

docs.title: ✅ requirements.txt
docs.text:
The traditional way to track dependencies:

# requirements.txt
requests==2.28.0
flask>=2.0.0
pytest>=7.0.0
numpy~=1.23.0

Version specifiers: - ==2.28.0 - Exact version - >=2.25.0 - Minimum version - <3.0.0 - Maximum version - ~=1.23.0 - Compatible release (1.23.x but not 1.24.0) - >=2.0,<3.0 - Range

Generate from current environment: 

pip freeze > requirements.txt

docs.title: ✅ pyproject.toml (Modern Standard)
docs.text:
The modern way to configure Python projects (PEP 518, 621):

[project]
name = "myproject"
version = "1.0.0"
description = "My awesome project"
requires-python = ">=3.9"
dependencies = [
    "requests>=2.25.0",
    "flask>=2.0.0",
]

[project.optional-dependencies]
dev = [
    "pytest>=7.0.0",
    "black",
    "mypy",
]

Install with: 

pip install .              # Install dependencies
pip install ".[dev]"       # Include dev dependencies

docs.title: ✅ Dependency Groups
docs.text:
Organize dependencies by purpose:

# requirements/base.txt
requests>=2.25.0
flask>=2.0.0

# requirements/dev.txt
-r base.txt
pytest>=7.0.0
black

# requirements/prod.txt
-r base.txt
gunicorn>=20.0.0

docs.title: ✅ Pinning vs Ranges
docs.text:
Approach Example Pros Cons Pinned requests==2.28.0 Reproducible May miss security fixes Range requests>=2.25,<3 Gets updates May break unexpectedly Compatible requests~=2.28 Balance Limited flexibility

Best practice: Pin in production, use ranges in libraries.

docs.title: ✅ Lock Files
docs.text:
Lock files record exact versions of all dependencies (including transitive):

  • pip freeze > requirements.lock
  • pip-tools: generates requirements.txt from requirements.in
  • poetry.lock, Pipfile.lock: managed by respective tools

docs.title: ✅ Modern Tools
docs.text: Tool Description pip-tools Compile requirements.in to requirements.txt Poetry All-in-one dependency + packaging management pipenv Combines pip + venv with Pipfile uv Fast pip/pip-tools replacement in Rust

docs.title: 🔍 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Use requirements.txt or pyproject.toml to track dependencies.
  • Pin versions for reproducible deployments.
  • Separate dev dependencies from production dependencies.
  • Use lock files to capture exact versions including transitive deps.

Back: Virtual Environments | Back to Module 13

docs.title: Question 1
docs.text:
What does pip freeze do?

  • A) Stops pip from running
  • B) Outputs installed packages with exact versions
  • C) Locks packages so they can't be updated
  • D) Removes all installed packages
Show Answer **B)** `pip freeze` outputs a list of installed packages with their exact versions in `package==version` format, suitable for creating a `requirements.txt` file.

docs.title: Question 2
docs.text:
What does the version specifier ~=1.4.0 mean?

  • A) Exactly version 1.4.0
  • B) Any version starting with 1.4 (>=1.4.0, <1.5.0)
  • C) Any version greater than 1.4.0
  • D) Any version less than 1.4.0
Show Answer **B)** The `~=` (compatible release) specifier allows patch updates but not minor/major updates. `~=1.4.0` means >=1.4.0 and <1.5.0.

docs.title: Question 3
docs.text:
What is the modern standard file for declaring Python project dependencies?

  • A) setup.py
  • B) requirements.txt
  • C) pyproject.toml
  • D) package.json
Show Answer **C)** `pyproject.toml` (defined in PEP 518, 621) is the modern standard for Python project configuration including dependencies. While `requirements.txt` is still widely used, `pyproject.toml` is the recommended approach.

docs.title: Question 4
docs.text:
Why should you pin dependency versions in production?

  • A) To make the code run faster
  • B) To ensure reproducible builds with known-working versions
  • C) To reduce file size
  • D) It's required by pip
Show Answer **B)** Pinning versions (e.g., `requests==2.28.0`) ensures everyone gets the exact same dependencies, making builds reproducible and avoiding surprises from unexpected updates.

docs.title: Question 5
docs.text:
What is a "transitive dependency"?

  • A) A package that's installed temporarily
  • B) A dependency of your dependency (indirect dependency)
  • C) A package that only works on certain platforms
  • D) A dependency that changes frequently
Show Answer **B)** Transitive dependencies are packages that your direct dependencies depend on. For example, if you install `flask`, you also get `werkzeug`, `jinja2`, etc. as transitive dependencies.

Back to Dependency Management README

docs.title: 🔍 Module 14: Debugging
docs.text:
Debugging is the process of finding and fixing bugs (defects) in your code. It's a critical skill that separates productive developers from frustrated ones.

This module covers: - Print debugging - The simplest and often most effective approach - Using debuggers - Step through code interactively with pdb - Reading tracebacks - Understand Python's error messages - Common bugs - Recognize and fix frequent mistakes

Estimated Time: 5-7 hours Prerequisites: Modules 01-08 Level: ⭐⭐⭐ Intermediate

docs.title: 📚 Topics Covered
docs.text: # Topic Description Key Concepts 01 Print Debugging Strategic print statements print(), f-strings, logging 02 Using Debuggers Interactive debugging with pdb breakpoint(), stepping, inspection 03 Reading Tracebacks Understanding error messages stack traces, exception chains 04 Common Bugs Frequent mistakes and fixes off-by-one, mutation, scope issues

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

  • Use print statements strategically to trace program flow.
  • Navigate the Python debugger (pdb) to step through code.
  • Read and interpret tracebacks to locate bugs quickly.
  • Recognize common bug patterns and know how to fix them.
  • Develop a systematic debugging mindset.
